Comfort, my liege; remember who you are.
Comfort, my liege; why looks your grace so pale?
Comfort, my lord; and so I take my leave.
Cominius, Marcius your old enemy,
Cominius, no.
Command an argosy to stem the waves.
Command these fretting waters from your eyes
Commanded always by the greater gust;
Commands me name myself.
Commend me to Lord William: tell him, Catesby,
Commend me to my brother: soon at night
Commend me to my wife. I'll return consul;
Commend me to thy brother, Edmund York.
Commend me to thy lady.
Commend my best obedience to the queen:
Commend them and condemn them to her service
Commit me for committing honour, trust it,

Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure
Committed by your person and your followers
Commonly are; the want of which vain dew
Commune with you of this, but rather follow
Communicatest with dreams;--how can this be?--
Compact with her that's gone, think'st thou thy oaths,
Compare dead happiness with living woe;
Compare her face with some that I shall show,
Complotted and contrived in this land
Comprising all that may be sworn or said,
Conceit, more rich in matter than in words,
Conceive when after many moody thoughts
Conceives by me! How likes Hortensio that?
Conceiving the dishonour of his mother,
Conceiving you: were I but twenty-one,
Concern me the reporting.
Concluding 'Stay: not yet.'
Condemn the fault and not the actor of it?
Condemn'd upon the act of fornication
Condemned villain, I do apprehend thee:
Condemning some to death, and some to exile;
Condemns you to the death. See them deliver'd over
Condition!
Conditionally, that here thou take an oath
Conduct me to the queen.
Confess the truth, and say by whose advice
Confess thy treasons ere thou fly the realm;
Confess who set thee up and pluck'd thee own,
Confess yourselves wondrous malicious,
Confess, confess, hath he not hit you here?
Confirm the crown to me and to mine heirs,
Conformable as other household Kates.
Confound your hidden falsehood, and award
Confounds thy fame as whirlwinds shake fair buds,
Confusion's near; I cannot speak. You, tribunes
Congeal'd with this, do make me wipe off both.
Conjectural marriages; making parties strong
Consenting to the safeguard of your honour,
Consider further,
Consider of it.'
Consider this: he has been bred i' the wars
Consider you what services he has done for his country?
Consisting equally of horse and foot;
Consort! what, dost thou make us minstrels? an
Consorted with that harlot strumpet Shore,
Constrains them weep and shake with fear and sorrow;
Construe them.
Consul! what consul?
Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.
Containing the deposing of a king
Contempt and beggary hangs upon thy back;
Contend against thy valour. Know thou first,
Content thee, gentle coz, let him alone;
Content you, gentlemen: I will compound this strife:
Content, content.
Content.
Content. What is the wager?
Contract us 'fore these witnesses.
Controlling majesty: alack, alack, for woe,
Convenient is it. Make a swift return;
Convenient numbers to make good the city;
Convey me to my bed, then to my grave:
Coriolanus banished!
Coriolanus in Corioli?
Coriolanus neither to care whether they love or hate
Coriolanus will carry it.
Coriolanus' exile. Now he's coming;
Coriolanus, that they are in a ripe aptness to take
Corioli like a planet: now all's his:
Corn for the rich men only: with these shreds
Correction and instruction must both work
Corrupt with virtuous season. Can it be
Costly apparel, tents, and canopies,
Could I repair what she will wear in me,
Could I with boot change for an idle plume,
Could all but answer for that peevish brat?
Could draw to part them, was stout Tybalt slain.
Could ever yet cut breath? Let no man mock me,
Could fetch your brother from the manacles
Could great men thunder
Could have attain'd the effect of your own purpose,
Could he not speak 'em fair?
Could he say less?
Could man so blench?
Could not abide to be with; therefore wast thou
Could not again undo: it was mine art,
Could not believe but that I was in hell,
Could not have made this peace.
Could not take truce with the unruly spleen
Could to no issue of true honour bring.
Could we but learn from whence his sorrows grow.
Could you not have told him
Could you not take some occasion without giving?
Counsel me, Tranio, for I know thou canst;
Counsel o' the war, but at his nurse's tears
Counting myself but bad till I be best.
County Anselme and his beauteous sisters; the lady
Courage! there will be pity taken on you: you that
Courage, man; the hurt cannot be much.
Courage, my masters! honour now or never!
Courageous Richmond, well hast thou acquit thee.
Courageously and with a free desire
Courtsied when you have and kiss'd
Cousin of Buckingham, a word with you.
Cousin of Buckingham, and you sage, grave men,

Cousin of Exeter, what thinks your lordship?
Cousin of Hereford, as thy cause is right,
Cousin of Hereford, what dost thou object
Cousin, I am too young to be your father,
Cousin, farewell: what presence must not know,
Cousin, farewell; and, uncle, bid him so:
Cousin, stand forth, and look upon that man.
Cousin, thou wert not wont to be so dull:
Cousin, throw up your gage; do you begin.
Cousins, indeed; and by their uncle cozen'd
Cover your heads and mock not flesh and blood
Craft against vice I must apply:
Crowd to his presence, where their untaught love
Crowns in my purse I have and goods at home,
Crowns what you are doing in the present deed,
Cry 'God save Richard, England's royal king!'
Cry 'Welcome, ladies, welcome!'
Cry but 'Ay me!' pronounce but 'love' and 'dove;'
Cry fie upon my grave!
Cry lost, and so good night!
Cry mercy, lords and watchful gentlemen,
Cry woe, destruction, ruin and decay:
Crying confusion.
Culling of simples; meagre were his looks,
Culling the principal of all the deer.
Cunning in music and the mathematics,
Currents that spring from one most gracious head,
Curse not thyself, fair creature thou art both.
Cursed be I that did so! All the charms
Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes!
Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it!
Cursed the blood that let this blood from hence!
Curster than she? why, 'tis impossible.
Cut me to pieces, Volsces; men and lads,
Cut off by course of justice,--
Cut off the heads of too fast growing sprays,
Cuts beauty off from all posterity.
Cuts off the ceremonious vows of love
Cyprus black as e'er was crow;

DUKE VINCENTIO:
DUKE:
Dabbled in blood; and he squeak'd out aloud,
Dally not with the gods, but get thee gone.
Dare he presume to scorn us in this manner?
Dare no more stretch this finger of mine than he
Dare not relate.
Dare rack his own: his subject am I not,
Dared once to touch a dust of England's ground?
Dares stir a wing, if Warwick shake his bells.
Darest thou resolve to kill a friend of mine?
Darest thou, thou little better thing than earth,
Darest with thy frozen admonition
Daring an opposite to every danger:
Dark cloudy death o'ershades his beams of life,
Darraign your battle, for they are at hand.
Dash'd all to pieces. O, the cry did knock
Dashes the fire out. O, I have suffered
Daughter, well met.
Day, night, hour, tide, time, work, play,
Day, yield me not thy light; nor, night, thy rest!
Dazzle mine eyes, or do I see three suns?
Dead art thou! Alack! my child is dead;
Dead to infliction, to themselves are dead;
Dear brother, how shall Bona be revenged
Dear earth, I do salute thee with my hand,
Dear for her reputation through the world,
Dear gentlewoman,
Dear life redeems you. You perceive she stirs:
Dear my brother,
Dear queen, that ended when I but began,
Dear sir, ere long I'll visit you again.
Dear, look up:
Death and destruction dog thee at the heels;
Death is a fearful thing.
Death is my son-in-law, Death is my heir;
Death lies on her like an untimely frost
Death makes no conquest of this conqueror;
Death on the wheel or at wild horses' heels,
Death to thyself but to thy lewd-tongued wife,
Death, desolation, ruin and decay:
Death, lie thou there, by a dead man interr'd.
Death, that dark spirit, in 's nervy arm doth lie;
Death, that hath suck'd the honey of thy breath,
Death, that hath ta'en her hence to make me wail,
Deceitful Warwick! it was thy device
Deceive more slily than Ulysses could,
Deceived in thy integrity, deceived
Deck'd in thy rights, as thou art stall'd in mine!
Decline all this, and see what now thou art:
Deep malice makes too deep incision;
Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile,
Defiance to the traitor, and so die?
Definitively thus I answer you.
Deformed, unfinish'd, sent before my time
Defy them then, or else hold close thy lips.
Delay leads impotent and snail-paced beggary
Delay this marriage for a month, a week;
Deliver them this paper: having read it,
Denounced against thee, are all fall'n upon thee;
Deny thy father and refuse thy name;
Deny your asking: take your choice of those
Depart again: here, here will I remain
Depose him in the justice of his cause.
Deposed he shall be, in despite of all.
Deposing thee before thou wert possess'd,
Depress'd he is already, and deposed
Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,
Deserve such pity of him as the wolf
Deserved this so dishonour'd rub, laid falsely
Deservedly confined into this rock,
Deserves the extremest death.
Deserves your hate; and your affections are
Desire the earl to see me in my tent:
Desire to breed by me. Here's flowers for you;
Desires access to you.
Desires you to attach his son, who has--
Desolate, desolate, will I hence and die:
Despair not, madam.
Despised substance of divinest show!
Despised, distressed, hated, martyr'd, kill'd!
Despite of death that lives upon my grave,
Despiteful tidings! O unpleasing news!
Destroy what lies before 'em.
Destroy'd his country, and his name remains
Destroy'd the sweet'st companion that e'er man
Destruction straight shall dog them at the heels.
Devised impeachments to imprison him :
Devouring pestilence hangs in our air
Di faciant laudis summa sit ista tuae!
Dicky your boy, that with his grumbling voice
Did I forget that by the house of York
Did I impale him with the regal crown?
Did I let pass the abuse done to my niece?
Did I not bid thee meet me in the park,
Did I put Henry from his native right?
Did Julius Caesar build that place, my lord?
Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven?
Did ever Dian so become a grove
Did ever dragon keep so fair a cave?
Did ever so long live; no sorrow
Did follow to his urn.
Did glad my heart with hope of this young Richmond,
Did grace our hollow parting with a tear.
Did it to help thee to a better husband.
Did keep ten thousand men? was this the face
Did make wolves howl and penetrate the breasts
Did murder her; as that name's cursed hand
Did my heart love till now? forswear it, sight!
Did never meddle with my thoughts.
Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order?
Did not attend him as we rode? I think
Did not deserve corn gratis. Being i' the war
Did not go forth of us, 'twere all alike
Did not offend, nor were not worthy blame,
Did not the one deserve to have an heir?
Did perish with the infant. 'Tis your counsel
Did prophesy that Richmond should be king,
Did scowl on gentle Richard; no man cried 'God save him!'
Did see and hear, devise, instruct, walk, feel,
Did shake down mellow fruit.
Did they not sometime cry, 'all hail!' to me?
Did this break-from her: 'Good Antigonus,
Did to thy father, steep'd in Rutland's blood,--
Did triumph in my face, and they are fled;
Did us but loving wrong.
Did utter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die:
Did verily bear blood?
Did will what he did spend and spent not that
Did you perceive
Did you such a thing?
Did you yet ever see Baptista's daughter?
Did, as he vouches, misreport your grace.
Didst break that vow; and with thy treacherous blade
Didst note it?
Didst perceive it?
Didst thou not hear me swear I would not do it?
Didst thou not kill this king?
Didst thou not mark the king, what words he spake,
Didst thou not say he comes?
Didst yield consent to disinherit him,
Die in his youth by like untimely violence!
Die neither mother, wife, nor England's queen!
Die, perish! Might but my bending down
Digest it with a custom, I should blush
Dighton and Forrest, whom I did suborn
Digressing from the valour of a man;
Dine with my father, drink a health to me;
Direct me, if it be your will,
Direct my sail! On, lusty gentlemen.
Direct not him whose way himself will choose:
Directitude! what's that?
Disbursed I duly to his highness' soldiers;
Discharge my followers: let them hence away,
Disclaiming here the kindred of the king,
Discomfortable cousin! know'st thou not
Dishonourable boy!
Dismantle you, and, as you can, disliken
Dismiss my soldiers, or capitulate
Dismiss them home.
Disorder, horror, fear and mutiny
Dispark'd my parks and fell'd my forest woods,
Dispatch it presently; the hour draws on
Dispatch, I prithee.
Dispatch, my lord; the duke would be at dinner:
Dispatch; the limit of your lives is out.
Displant a town, reverse a prince's doom,
Dispose of her
Dispose of you.
Dispropertied their freedoms, holding them,
Dispute not with her; she is lunatic.
Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.
Dissentious numbers pestering streets than see
Distinguish form: so your sweet majesty,
Dive, thoughts, down to my soul: here
Divide in all with us.
Divided in their dire division,
Divides one thing entire to many objects;
Divine his downfall? Say, where, when, and how,
Divinely bent to meditation;
Do I live dead that live to tell it now.
Do all lie there: it shall be so my care
Do as the carrion does, not as the flower,
Do as the heavens have done, forget your evil;
Do as thou wilt, for I have done with thee.
Do bid it welcome.
Do but mistake.
Do climate here! You have a holy father,
Do come with words as medicinal as true,
Do curse the gout, serpigo, and the rheum,
Do ebb and flow with tears; the bark thy body is,
Do even drag me homeward: which to hinder
Do get their children; but in this case of wooing,
Do give a life: no shepherdess, but Flora
Do lace the severing clouds in yonder east:
Do light upon her, she shall bring him that
Do make myself a suitor to your daughter,
Do me but right, and you must all confess
Do me this right; hear me with patience.
Do more than counterpoise a full third part
Do not believe it. Fewness and truth, 'tis thus:
Do not cry havoc, where you should but hunt
Do not deny to him that you love me.
Do not draw the curtain.
Do not omit the heavy offer of it:
Do not repent these things, for they are heavier
Do not stand upon't.
Do not swear at all;
Do not you fear: upon mine honour,
Do plainly give you out an unstain'd shepherd,
Do press among the popular throngs and puff
Do right unto this princely Duke of York,
Do seem to be of ours?
Do smilingly revolt; and who resist
Do so, and after two days
Do so, and bid my sweet prepare to chide.
Do so, it is a point of wisdom: fare you well.
Do strike at my injustice.
Do their best office, if they can but stay you
Do then: but I'll not hear.
Do they still fly to the Roman?
Do thou but call my resolution wise,
Do thou but close our hands with holy words,
Do through the clouds behold this present hour,
Do what thou canst, I will not go to-day;
Do what you can, yours will not be entreated.
Do with your injuries as seems you best,
Do wound the bark, the skin of our fruit-trees,
Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
Do you bite your thumb at us, sir?
Do you call, sir?
Do you hear how he misplaces?
Do you hear how we are shent for keeping your
Do you hear, ho? you must meet my master to
Do you hear, sir? To leave frivolous circumstances,
Do you hear?
Do you intend to stay with me tonight?
Do you neglect them?
Do you not hear him? You mar our labour: keep your
Do you not hear me speak?
Do you not see that I am out of breath?
Do you not smile at this, Lord Angelo?
Do you persuade yourself that I respect you?
Do you quarrel, sir?
Do you so, sir? And was the duke a fleshmonger, a
Do you the office, friar; which consummate,
Do you your office, or give up your place,
Do your will.
Do't and thou hast the one half of my heart;
Do't not, thou split'st thine own.
Do't! he will do't; for, look you, sir, he has as
Do, Paulina;
Do, and be witness to 't.
Do, good my lord, lest all the land do rue it.
Do, good my lord, your citizens entreat you.
Do, good old grandsire; and withal make known
Does Bridget paint still, Pompey, ha?
Does change my disposition.
Does my deeds make the blacker!
Does not approve me further, who was wont
Does of the shepherds: for his best friends, if they
Does reason our petition with more strength
Does your worship mean to geld and splay all the
Dogs howl'd, and hideous tempest shook down trees;
Dogs, easily won to fawn on any man!
Doing annoyance to the treacherous feet
Doing more murders in this loathsome world,
Dolour comes to him, indeed: you
Done many things, some less, some more your voices:
Done. The wager?
Dorset your son, that with a fearful soul
Dorset, embrace him; Hastings, love lord marquess.
Dost grant me, hedgehog? then, God grant me too
Dost lack any money? I have a little money for thee.
Dost think I am so muddy, so unsettled,
Dost thou attend me?
Dost thou desire her foully for those things
Dost thou detest her therefore?
Dost thou forget
Dost thou hear?
Dost thou love hawking? thou hast hawks will soar
Dost thou love me? I know thou wilt say 'Ay,'
Dost thou love pictures? we will fetch thee straight
Dost thou not bring me letters from the friar?
Dost thou not laugh?
Dost thou teach pardon pardon to destroy?
Doth add more grief to too much of mine own.
Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me
Doth cloud my joys with danger and with sorrow.
Doth couch his limbs, there golden sleep doth reign:
Doth fancy any other but Lucentio?
Doth flourish the deceit. Come, let us go:
Doth grace for grace and love for love allow;
Doth he so seek his life?
Doth hurry from the fatal cannon's womb.
Doth it not then our eyelids sink? I find not
Doth live again in thee: long mayst thou live
Doth love my daughter and she loveth him,
Doth make against me of this direful murder;
Doth more solicit me than your exclaims,
Doth much excuse the appertaining rage
Doth my name lodge? tell me, that I may sack
Doth not the object cheer your heart, my lord?
Doth not thy embassage belong to me,
Doth set my pugging tooth on edge;
Doth she not think me an old murderer,
Doth this news hold of good King Edward's death?
Doth watch Bianca's steps so narrowly,
Doth with a twofold vigour lift me up
Doth your honour see any harm in his face?
Doting like me and like me banished,
Double and treble admonition, and still forfeit in
Doubly divorced! Bad men, you violate
Doubly portcullis'd with my teeth and lips;
Doubt not
Dove-feather'd raven! wolvish-ravening lamb!
Down with him! down with him!
Down with him, down with him!
Down with that sword! Tribunes, withdraw awhile.
Down with the Capulets! down with the Montagues!
Down with the topmast! yare! lower, lower! Bring
Down, down I come; like glistering Phaethon,
Down, down to hell; and say I sent thee thither:
Down, ladies; let us shame him with our knees.
Draw forth thy weapon, we are beset with thieves;
Draw near,
Draw near, Queen Margaret, and be a witness
Draw near, ye people.
Draw, Benvolio; beat down their weapons.
Draw, if you be men. Gregory, remember thy swashing blow.
Drawn tuns of blood out of thy country's breast,
Drawn with a team of little atomies
Draws out our miles, and makes them wearisome,
Draws the sweet infant breath of gentle sleep;
Dreaming on both; for all thy blessed youth
Dreamt of encounters 'twixt thyself and me;
Drest in a little brief authority,
Drinking my griefs, whilst you mount up on high.
Driving back shadows over louring hills:
Droop not; adieu. Farewell, my wife, my mother:
Drop on you both! a south-west blow on ye
Drop-heir that killed lusty Pudding, and Master
Dropping upon thy head.
Drown desperate sorrow in dead Edward's grave,
Drummer, strike up, and let us march away.
Drums in his ear, at which he starts and wakes,
Dry sorrow drinks our blood. Adieu, adieu!
Dry up your tears, and stick your rosemary
Duck with French nods and apish courtesy,
Dukes, earls, lords, gentlemen; indeed, of all.
Dull thing, I say so; he, that Caliban
Dull, unmindful villain,
During his power, go sleep.
During the wars of York and Lancaster
Dwelt by a churchyard: I will tell it softly;
E'en at hand, alighted by this; and therefore be

Each day still better other's happiness;
Each in his office ready at thy beck.
Each one already blazing by our meeds,
Each one demand an answer to his part
Each part, deprived of supple government,
Each substance of a grief hath twenty shadows,
Each way, to better yours.
Each word thou hast spoke hath weeded from my heart
Earl of Northumberland, he slew thy father.
Earth gapes, hell burns, fiends roar, saints pray.
Earth-treading stars that make dark heaven light:
Eating the bitter bread of banishment;
Edward Plantagenet, arise a knight;
Edward Plantagenet, why art thou dead?
Edward and Clarence. O, what cause have I,
Edward and Richard, like a brace of greyhounds
Edward and Richard, you shall stay with me;
Edward and York; then haply she will weep:
Edward for Edward pays a dying debt.
Edward the Fourth, by the grace of God, king of
Edward thy son, which now is Prince of Wales,
Edward will always bear himself as king:
Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one,
Edward, her lord, whom I, some three months since,
Edward, kneel down.
Edward, my lord, your son, our king, is dead.
Edward, what satisfaction canst thou make
Either I must, or have mine honour soil'd
Either be gone before the watch be set,
Either be patient, and entreat me fair,
Either betray'd by falsehood of his guard
Either for life or death, upon the earth
Either forbear,
Either heaven with lightning strike the
Either his gracious promise, which you might,
Either my eyesight fails, or thou look'st pale.
Either new, or by remissness new-conceived,
Either of condemnation or approof;
Either of you to be the other's end.
Either that is thine, or else thou wert not his.
Either this is the envy in you, folly, or mistaking:
Either thou art most ignorant by age,
Either thou wilt die, by God's just ordinance,
Either thou, or I, or both, must go with him.
Either withdraw unto some private place,
Either you must
Elected him our absence to supply,
Eleven hours I spent to write it over,
Eleven, sir.
Else let my brother die,
Else might I think that Clarence, Edward's brother,
Else wherefore breathe I in a Christian land?
Else would I tear the cave where Echo lies,
Else would a maiden blush bepaint my cheek
Else, when he's found, that hour is his last.
Ely with Richmond troubles me more near
Embarquements all of fury, shall lift up
Embrace each other's love in banishment;
Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:
End in a word: such is the breath of kings.
Endue you with the people's voice: remains
Endured all weathers.
Endured of her, for whom you bid like sorrow.
Enforce attention like deep harmony:
Enforce him with his envy to the people,
Enforce the present execution
Enforced thee! art thou king, and wilt be forced?
Enforced us to this execution?
Enfranchisement immediate on his knees:
Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.
Engage it to the trial, if thou darest.
England and France, and lord of Ireland, &c.
England hath long been mad, and scarr'd herself;
England is safe, if true within itself?
England, bound in with the triumphant sea
Enjoy the kingdom after my decease.
Enjoy your mistress, from the whom, I see,
Enough of this; I pray thee, hold thy peace.
Enough then for your wonder. But, come on,
Enough, my lord.
Enough, with over-measure.
Enrich the time to come with smooth-faced peace,
Ensues his piteous and unpitied end:
Ensuing dangers; as by proof, we see
Envelope you, good Provost! Who call'd here of late?
Envied against the people, seeking means
Environ'd me about, and howled in mine ears
Environed he was with many foes,
Environed with all these hideous fears?
Equal with wondering: what of her ensues
Ere I again behold my Romeo!
Ere I could make thee open thy white hand
Ere I let fall the windows of mine eyes:
Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced.
Ere a fortnight make me elder,
Ere from this war thou turn a conqueror,
Ere further leisure yield them further means
Ere he attain his easeful western bed:
Ere he can spread his sweet leaves to the air,
Ere he express himself, or move the people
Ere he would have hanged a man for the getting a
Ere he, that should be husband, comes to woo.
Ere now denied the asker? and now again
Ere one can say 'It lightens.' Sweet, good night!
Ere so prevail'd with me: it will in time
Ere stay behind this business.
Ere sun-rise, prayers from preserved souls,
Ere they lack'd power to cross you.
Ere this rude beast will profit.
Ere three days pass, which hath as long loved me
Ere twice the sun hath made his journal greeting
Ere we may think her ripe to be a bride.
Ere ye come there, be sure to hear some news.
Ere yet the fight be done, pack up: down with them!
Ere you can say 'she's honest:' but be 't known,
Ere you were queen, yea, or your husband king,
Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.
Err'd in this point which now you censure him,
Erroneous vassal! the great King of kings
Erroneous, mutinous and unnatural,
Error i' the bill, sir; error i' the bill.
Escalus.
Especially in pride.
Esteem as foil wherein thou art to set
Even all I have; yea, and myself and all,
Even as a flattering dream or worthless fancy.
Even as she speaks, why, their hearts were yours;
Even as the waving sedges play with wind.
Even as thou wilt, sweet Warwick, let it be;
Even at his feet to lay my arms and power,
Even by your own.
Even for revenge mock my destruction!
Even for the loss of thee, having no more,
Even for your son's sake; and thereby for sealing
Even from the tongueless caverns of the earth,
Even from this instant, banish him our city,
Even he that makes her queen who should be else?
Even he, Biondello.
Even he, my lord.
Even he, your wife, this lady, and myself,
Even here undone!
Even in condition of the worst degree,
Even in his own garments, and gave himself,
Even in so short a space, my woman's heart
Even in the afternoon of her best days,
Even in the best blood chamber'd in his bosom.
Even in the chair of state: belike he means,
Even in the downfall of his mellow'd years,
Even in the lukewarm blood of Henry's heart.
Even in the lusty havior of his son.
Even in theirs and in the commons' ears,
Even in these honest mean habiliments:
Even in these looks I made.
Even like a fawning greyhound in the leash,
Even like an o'ergrown lion in a cave,
Even now forsake me, and of all my lands
Even now the frozen bosom of the north,
Even now we heard the news: ah, could'st thou fly!
Even of your mettle, of your very blood;
Even or odd, of all days in the year,
Even pushes 'gainst our heart: the party tried
Even since it could speak, from an infant, freely
Even so
Even so as I mine own course have set down:
Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart;
Even so, or with much more contempt, men's eyes
Even so. Heaven keep your honour!
Even so; an't please your worship, Brakenbury,
Even such a woman oweth to her husband;
Even such, they say, as stand in narrow lanes,
Even that, I hope, which pleaseth God above,
Even then that sunshine brew'd a shower for him,
Even then will rush to knowledge. Go: fresh horses!
Even thou and none but thou. Take it up straight:
Even to Cato's wish, not fierce and terrible
Even to a full disgrace. Best of my flesh,
Even to my person, than I thought he would
Even to the court, the heart, to the seat o' the brain;
Even to the frozen ridges of the Alps,
Even to the general all-ending day.
Even to the guilt or the purgation.
Even to the uttermost, as I please, in words.
Even to their ships.
Even when the navel of the state was touch'd,
Even when you please, since you will have it so.
Even where his lustful eye or savage heart,
Even with such life of majesty, warm life,
Even with the dearest blood your bodies bear.
Even with the same austerity and garb
Even with the stroke and line of his great justice:
Ever right.
Ever to conquer, and to have his worth
Evermore cross'd and cross'd; nothing but cross'd!
Evermore showering? In one little body
Evermore thanks, the exchequer of the poor;
Evermore weeping for your cousin's death?
Every good hap to you that chances here:
Every letter he hath writ hath disvouched other.
Every man's conscience is a thousand swords,
Every true man's apparel fits your thief: if it be
Exactly is perform'd: but there's more work.
Examine every married lineament,
Examine other beauties.
Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee,
Exceeds, in that, the lists of all advice
Excels whatever yet you look'd upon
Except like curs to tear us all to pieces.
Except the marshal and such officers
Excepting one, I would he were the best
Execute all things; for no kind of traffic
Exempt from envy, but not from disdain,
Exeter, so will I.
Exeter, thou art a traitor to the crown
Expedient manage must be made, my liege,
Exposed this paragon to the fearful usage,
Expresseth his full tilth and husbandry.
Exton, I thank thee not; for thou hast wrought

Face not me: thou hast braved many men; brave not
Fain would I dwell on form, fain, fain deny
Fair Leda's daughter had a thousand wooers;
Fair Queen of England, worthy Margaret,
Fair cousin, you debase your princely knee
Fair lords, take leave and stand not to reply.
Fair lovely maid, once more good day to thee.
Fair sir, and you my merry mistress,
Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have
Fairly offer'd.
Faith, I can tell her age unto an hour.
Faith, I know not what to say.
Faith, as cold as can be.
Faith, as you say, there's small choice in rotten
Faith, gentlemen, now I play a merchant's part,
Faith, he is gone unto the taming-school.
Faith, here it is.
Faith, look you, one cannot tell how to say that:
Faith, mistress, then I have no cause to stay.
Faith, none for me; except the north-east wind,
Faith, none, but Humphrey Hour, that call'd
Faith, nothing; but has left me here behind, to
Faith, sir, few of any wit in such matters: as they
Faith, sir, if you had told as many lies in his
Faith, sirrah, an you'll not knock, I'll ring it;
Faith, there had been many great men that have
Faith, we hear fearful news.
Faith, we may put up our pipes, and be gone.
Fall deep in love with thee; and her great charms
Fall like amazing thunder on the casque
Fall to the base earth from the firmament.
Fall to them as you find your stomach serves you;
Falls into forfeit: he arrests him on it;
False accusation blush and tyranny
False to his children or his wife's allies
False to my nature? Rather say I play
False-boding woman, end thy frantic curse,
Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.
Falsely to take away a life true made
Fame, at the which he aims,
Familiarly shall call thy Dorset brother;
Famous Plantagenet, most gracious prince,
Fan you into despair! Have the power still
Fancies too weak for boys, too green and idle
Far be it from my heart, the thought of it!
Far be the thought of this from Henry's heart,
Far than Deucalion off: mark thou my words:
Fare ye well:
Fare you well.
Farewell at once, for once, for all, and ever.
Farewell till soon.
Farewell!
Farewell! God knows when we shall meet again.
Farewell, York's wife, and queen of sad mischance:
Farewell, ancient lady; farewell,
Farewell, dear father!
Farewell, faint-hearted and degenerate king,
Farewell, farewell! one kiss, and I'll descend.
Farewell, farewell.
Farewell, good Pompey. Commend me to the prison,
Farewell, good cousin; farewell, gentle friends.
Farewell, good friar: I prithee, pray for me. The
Farewell, kind neighbours: we wish'd Coriolanus
Farewell, my Hector, and my Troy's true hope.
Farewell, my blood; which if to-day thou shed,
Farewell, my coz.
Farewell, my gracious lord; I'll to my castle.
Farewell, my liege. Now no way can I stray;
Farewell, my lord. Light to my chamber, ho!
Farewell, my lord: securely I espy
Farewell, my sovereign.
Farewell, old Gaunt: thy sometimes brother's wife
Farewell, our brother.
Farewell, sweet lords: let's meet at Coventry.
Farewell, sweet masters both; I must be gone.
Farewell, thou woful welcomer of glory!
Farewell.
Farewell.
Farewell.
Farewell: buy food, and get thyself in flesh.
Farewell: if heart's presages be not vain,
Farewell: our countrymen are gone and fled,
Farewell: the leisure and the fearful time
Farewell: thou canst not teach me to forget.
Farewell; be trusty, and I'll quit thy pains:
Farewell; commend me to thy mistress.
Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might
Fasten'd and fix'd the shame on't in himself,
Faster than thought or time.
Fatal and ominous to noble peers!
Fated to the purpose did Antonio open
Father of Warwick, know you what this means?
Father, 'tis thus: yourself and all the world,
Father, and wife, and gentlemen, adieu;
Father, be quiet; he shall stay my leisure.
Father, tear the crown from the usurper's head.
Father, what news? what is the prince's doom?
Father, you cannot disinherit me:
Father:
Father:
Father:
Father:
Faults proper to himself: if he had so offended,
Favours that keep within. Come, Escalus,
Fear and be slain; no worse can come to fight:
Fear me not.
Fear me not.
Fear none of this: I think you know my fortunes
Fear not our care, sir.
Fear not that, my lord.
Fear not thou, man, thou shalt lose nothing here.
Fear not, Baptista; we will content you, go to: but
Fear not, my lord, I'll play the orator
Fear not, my lord, we will not stand to prate;
Fear not, my lord: that Power that made you king
Fear not, my lord: we can contain ourselves,
Fear not, sweet wench, they shall not touch
Fear you his tyrannous passion more, alas,
Fear you not him. Sirrah Biondello,
Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
Fear'd by their breed and famous by their birth,
Fear, and not love, begets his penitence:
Feast with the best, and welcome to my house:
Feather of lead, bright smoke, cold fire,
Feed not thy sovereign's foe, my gentle earth,
Feeling so the loss,
Fell Warwick's brother and by that our foe.
Fell gently down, as if they struck their friends.
Fell sorrow's tooth doth never rankle more
Fellow Grumio!
Fellow, give place; here is no longer stay.
Fellow, why dost thou show me thus to the world?
Fellows in arms, and my most loving friends,
Fertile the isle, the temple much surpassing
Fetch from false Mowbray their first head and spring.
Fetch hither Richard, that in common view
Fetch in our wood and serves in offices
Fetch me my rapier, boy. What dares the slave
Fetch us in fuel; and be quick, thou'rt best,
Few words suffice; and therefore, if thou know
Fiddler, forbear; you grow too forward, sir:
Fie on her! see, how beastly she doth court him!
Fie! what a foolish duty call you this?
Fie, daughter! when my old wife lived, upon
Fie, doff this habit, shame to your estate,
Fie, fie on all tired jades, on all mad masters, and
Fie, fie! no thought of him:
Fie, fie! unknit that threatening unkind brow,
Fie, fie! what, are you mad?
Fie, fie, fie!
Fie, fie, fie!
Fie, fie, thou shamest thy shape, thy love, thy wit;
Fie, how my bones ache! what a jaunt have I had!
Fie, sirrah! a bawd, a wicked bawd!
Fie, what a slug is Hastings, that he comes not
Fie, what a spendthrift is he of his tongue!
Fie, what an indirect and peevish course
Fie, you confine yourself most unreasonably: come,
Fiend, thou torment'st me ere I come to hell!
Fifth Citizen:
Fights dragon-like, and does achieve as soon
Fill all thy bones with aches, make thee roar
Fill me a bowl of wine. Give me a watch.
Fill'd it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.
Filling the air with swords advanced and darts,
Fillip the stars; then let the mutinous winds
Filth as thou art, with human care, and lodged thee
Find in myself no pity to myself?
Find shapes of grief, more than himself, to wail;
Find them out whose names are written here! It is
Find thou the means, and I'll find such a man.
Find written in the margent of his eyes.
Finding yourself desired of such a person,
Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur?
Fine apparition! My quaint Ariel,
Fine linen, Turkey cushions boss'd with pearl,

First hand me: on mine own accord I'll off;
First if all obstacles were cut away,
First kiss me, Kate, and we will.
First were we sad, fearing you would not come;
First will I see the coronation;
First, an it like you, the house is a respected
First, as you know, my house within the city
First, he commends him to your noble lordship.
First, hear me speak.
First, heaven be the record to my speech!
First, know, my horse is tired; my master and
First, let her show her face, and after speak.
First, madam, I entreat true peace of you,
First, mighty sovereign, let me know your mind,
First, provost, let me bail these gentle three.
First, tell me, have you ever been at Pisa?
First, the fair reverence of your highness curbs me
First, the gods bless you for your tidings; next,
First, to do greetings to thy royal person;
First, to thy sacred state wish I all happiness.
First, you know Caius Marcius is chief enemy to the people.
Fit for her turn, well read in poetry
Fit thy consent to my sharp appetite;
Fit to instruct her youth. If you, Hortensio,
Fitzwater, thou art damn'd to hell for this.
Five have I slain to-day instead of him.
Five justices' hands at it, and witnesses more than
Five men to twenty! though the odds be great,
Five times in that ere once in our five wits.
Five tribunes to defend their vulgar wisdoms,
Flatter my sorrows with report of it;
Flattering me with impossibilities.
Fled from his father, from his hopes, and with
Flies may do this, but I from this must fly:
Flock to their aid, and still their power increaseth.
Flow'd with her beauty once: 'tis shrewdly ebb'd,
Flower as she was, deflowered by him.
Flower of warriors,
Flutter'd your Volscians in Corioli:
Fly hence, and leave me: think upon these gone;
Fly to the duke:
Fly, father, fly! for all your friends are fled,
Foes to my rest and my sweet sleep's disturbers
Follow me close, for I will speak to them.
Follow me.
Follow thine enemy in a fiery gulf
Follow us to the court. Thou churl, for this time,
Follow your function, go, and batten on cold bits.
Following the fliers at the very heels,
Fool, fool! thou whet'st a knife to kill thyself.
Fool, of thyself speak well: fool, do not flatter.
Fool-hardiness; not I.
Foot it featly here and there;
For 'tis a sign of love; and love to Richard
For 'tis a sore upon us,
For 'tis a throne where honour may be crown'd
For 'tis most dangerous.
For 'tis the mind that makes the body rich;
For 'tis thy presence that exhales this blood
For 'twas your heaven she should be advanced:
For 'twere no charity; yet, to wash your blood
For Angelo,
For Christian service and true chivalry,
For Clarence is well-spoken, and perhaps
For Edward my son, which was Prince of Wales,
For Edward will defend the town and thee,
For Edward's sake; and see how he requites me!
For Edward, for my brother, for his sake: Why, sirs,
For Gloucester's dukedom is too ominous.
For God he knows, and you may partly see,
For God's sake, a pot of small ale.
For God's sake, fairly let her be entreated:
For God's sake, let not us two be behind;
For God's sake, let us sit upon the ground
For God's sake, lords, give signal to the fight.
For God's sake, take away this captive scold.
For I am all the subjects that you have,
For I am he am born to tame you Kate,
For I am loath to break our country's laws.
For I am proverb'd with a grandsire phrase;
For I am rough and woo not like a babe.
For I am she, and altogether joyless.
For I can here disarm thee with this stick
For I come hither arm'd against myself:
For I dare so far free him--made him fear'd,
For I do fear eyes over--to shipboard
For I had then laid wormwood to my dug,
For I have bills for money by exchange
For I have bought it with an hundred blows.
For I have ever verified my friends,
For I have given here my soul's consent
For I have had such faults; but rather tell me,
For I have heard it said
For I have heard that she was there in place.
For I have more to commune with Bianca.
For I have murdered where I should not kill.
For I have need of many orisons
For I have none: let no man speak again
For I have often heard my mother say
For I intend but only to surprise him.
For I must hence; and farewell to you all.
For I myself am not so well provided
For I myself have many tears to wash
For I myself will hunt this wolf to death.
For I ne'er saw true beauty till this night.
For I repent me that the duke is slain.
For I shall never speak to thee again.
For I will board her, though she chide as loud
For I will buz abroad such prophecies
For I will hence to Warwick's other daughter;
For I will henceforth be no more unconstant.
For I will kiss her.
For I will love thee ne'er the less, my girl.
For I will raise her statue in pure gold;
For I would commune with you of such things
For I, too fond, might have prevented this.
For Jesu Christ in glorious Christian field,
For Juliet's sake, for her sake, rise and stand;
For King of England shalt thou be proclaim'd
For Margaret my queen, and Clifford too,
For Mariana's sake: but as he adjudged your brother,--
For Mowbray and myself are like two men
For Richard, in the view of many lords,
For Rome, towards Marcius.
For Somerset, off with his guilty head.
For Venus smiles not in a house of tears.
For Warwick and his friends, God and Saint George!
For Warwick bids you all farewell to meet in heaven.
For Warwick is a subtle orator,
For Warwick was a bug that fear'd us all.
For York in justice puts his armour on.
For a quart of ale is a dish for a king.
For a reply, at least if you make a care
For a short holding: if we lose the field,
For a worthy lady
For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.
For all the Welshmen, hearing thou wert dead.
For all the accommodations that thou bear'st
For all the rest is held at such a rate
For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.
For at their hands I have deserved no pity.
For aught I know, my lord, they do.
For bearing arms, for stirring up my subjects,
For beauty starved with her severity
For being a bawd, for being a bawd.
For being a little bad: so may my husband.
For being more stone than it? O royal piece,
For better times to come. Friar, advise him;
For blood of ours, shed blood of Montague.
For both hast thou, and both become the grave.
For both of you are birds of selfsame feather.
For both our sakes, I would that word were true.
For by his face straight shall you know his heart.
For by my scouts I was advertised
For by that loss I will not purchase them.
For certain drops of salt, your city Rome,
For certain words he spake against your grace
For chair and dukedom, throne and kingdom say;
For choosing me when Clarence is in place.
For common justice, you're as pregnant in
For corn at their own rates; whereof, they say,
For curious I cannot be with you,
For dainties are all Kates, and therefore, Kate,
For death, for fine, or banishment, then let them
For did I but suspect a fearful man
For divers unknown reasons. I beseech you,
For do we must what force will have us do.
For doing worthy vengeance on thyself,
For doting, not for loving, pupil mine.
For doubtless Burgundy will yield him help,
For emulation now, who shall be nearest,
For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth nor age,
For even the day before, she broke her brow:
For ever
For ever may my knees grow to the earth,
For ever will I walk upon my knees,
For every cloud engenders not a storm.
For every inch of woman in the world,
For every man that Bolingbroke hath press'd
For every pelting, petty officer
For exile hath more terror in his look,
For fair without the fair within to hide:
For false forswearing and for murder too:
For fear of that, I still will stay with thee;
For fear, I promise you, if I look pale.
For few men rightly temper with the stars:
For first he was contract to Lady Lucy--
For from my heart thine image ne'er shall go;
For gay apparel 'gainst the triumph day.
For girls of nine, O, think what they have done
For gnarling sorrow hath less power to bite
For had I cursed now, I had cursed myself.
For half a hundred years. Summon the town.
For hand to hand he would have vanquish'd thee.
For happy wife, a most distressed widow;
For hardy and undoubted champions;
For has not the divine Apollo said,
For hateful deeds committed by myself!
For he fears none.
For he hath still been tried a holy man.
For he is just and always loved us well.
For he is nothing but a mighty lord.
For he that interrupts him shall not live.
For he was fitter for that place than earth.
For her poor brother's pardon.
For her, my lord,
For here lies Juliet, and her beauty makes
For here we need it not.
For here, I hope, begins our lasting joy.
For him thou labour'st by thy flight to shun
For him, I partly know his mind--to find thee
For him, poor soul. The proudest of you all
For his advantage that I dearly love.
For his designs crave haste, his haste good hope:
For hither we have broken in by force.
For hither will our friends repair to us.
For how I firmly am resolved you know;
For how can I help them, and not myself?
For how can tyrants safely govern home,
For hunting was his daily exercise.
For in Baptista's keep my treasure is:
For in a minute there are many days:
For in a quarrel since I came ashore
For in an act of this importance 'twere
For in the marches here we heard you were,
For in this sin he is as deep as I.
For in thy shoulder do I build my seat,
For inequality; but let your reason serve
For insurrection's arguing.
For it engenders choler, planteth anger;
For it excels your first: or if it did not,
For it is done, my lord.
For it requires the royal debt it lent you.
For it was bad enough before their spite.
For joyful mother, one that wails the name;
For kissing, lady, not for such contempt.
For learning me your language!
For love of Edward's offspring in my womb:
For making me, so young, so old a widow!
For making up this peace!' Thou know'st, great son,
For man or master; then it follows thus;
For many lives stand between me and home:
For many men that stumble at the threshold
For matching more for wanton lust than honour,
For me as for you?
For me to joy and weep their gain and loss:
For me to try how: all I know of it
For me, I'll not be gone till I please myself:
For me, if I be gored with Mowbray's spear:
For me, that I may surely keep mine oath,
For me, the ransom of my bold attempt
For men so old as we to keep the peace.
For mercy to his country. Therefore, let's hence,
For mine own part,
For mischiefs manifold and sorceries terrible
For mocking marriage with a dame of France.
For more amazement. If you can behold it,
For most it caught me, the celestial habits,
For my authority bears of a credent bulk,
For my lads to give their dears:
For my part, I'll not trouble thee with words.
For my part, I'll resign unto your grace
For my poor brother's head.
For my prosperity!
For my wounds' sake, to give their suffrage: please you
For never henceforth shall I joy again,
For never was a story of more woe
For never yet one hour in his bed
For night-owls shriek where mounting larks
For no less spoil than glory,--
For no thought is contented. The better sort,
For nothing but his majesty's approach.
For nothing can be ill, if she be well.
For nothing had begot my something grief;
For nought so vile that on the earth doth live
For now hath time made me his numbering clock:
For now he lives in fame, though not in life.
For now the devil, that told me I did well,
For now they kill me with a living death.
For now we owe allegiance unto Henry.
For now we sit to chat as well as eat.
For now, these hot days, is the mad blood stirring.
For of joy, being altogether wanting,
For on my heart they tread now whilst I live;
For on that ground I'll build a holy descant:
For on thy fortune I repose myself.
For once allow'd the skilful pilot's charge?
For one being fear'd of all, now fearing one;
For one being sued to, one that humbly sues;
For one commanding all, obey'd of none.
For one poor grain or two!
For one poor grain or two, to leave unburnt,
For one that scorn'd at me, now scorn'd of me;
For one to thrust his hand between his teeth,
For our access, whose hap shall be to have her
For our affairs in hand: if that come short,
For our case is as theirs.
For our first merriment hath made thee jealous.
For patience she will prove a second Grissel,
For present comfort and for future good,
For private quarrel 'twixt your duke and him,
For queen, a very caitiff crown'd with care;
For raging wind blows up incessant showers,
For raising this sea-storm?
For saints have hands that pilgrims' hands do touch,
For selfsame wind that I should speak withal
For shame! leave Henry, and call Edward king.
For shame, bring Juliet forth; her lord is come.
For shame, come down: he made thee Duke of York.
For shame, my liege, make them your precedent!
For shame, thou helding of a devilish spirit,
For she did print your royal father off,
For she is changed, as she had never been.
For she is good, hath brought you forth a daughter;
For she is sweeter than perfume itself
For she's a woman to be pitied much:
For she's not froward, but modest as the dove;
For sinking under them.
For sleeping England long time have I watch'd;
For so I have strew'd it in the common ear,
For so I see she must be, 'fore Leontes:
For so he said he would: I hear him near.
For so your doctors hold it very meet,
For so your father charged me at our parting,
For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done.
For sorrow's eye, glazed with blinding tears,
For standing by when Richard stabb'd her son.
For still 'tis beating in my mind, your reason
For still thy eyes, which I may call the sea,
For stony limits cannot hold love out,
For strokes received, and many blows repaid,
For such a one as leaves a gentleman,
For such a warped slip of wilderness
For such a wish! he was not born to shame:
For such an injury would vex a very saint,
For suffering so the causes of our wreck.
For sweet discourses in our time to come.
For taking so the head, your whole head's length.
For tender princes, use my babies well!
For terror, not to use, in time the rod
For testimony whereof, one in the prison,
For that 'Forgive our Romans.' O, a kiss
For that I was his father Edward's son;
For that he has,
For that he knew you, might reproach your life
For that her reputation was disvalued
For that it made my imprisonment a pleasure;
For that my sovereign liege was in my debt
For that our kingdom's earth should not be soil'd
For that which thou hast heard me speak to-night
For that which, if myself might be his judge,
For that's the utmost of his pilgrimage.
For that, being one o' the lowest, basest, poorest,
For the benefit of silence, would thou wert so too!
For the deposing of a rightful king.
For the flowers now, that frighted thou let'st fall
For the in which doth control't.
For the inheritance of their loves and safeguard
For the instalment of this noble duke
For the most gentle Claudio.
For the mutable, rank-scented many, let them
For the red blood reigns in the winter's pale.
For the whole state, I would put mine armour on,
For thee to murder: for my daughters, Richard,
For their advantage and your highness' loss.
For their own good and ours.
For them to play at will. How came the posterns
For them! I cannot do it to the gods;
For then I pity those I do not know,
For then I'll marry Warwick's youngest daughter.
For then she could stand alone; nay, by the rood,
For then she never looks upon her lure.
For then this land was famously enrich'd
For then thou canst not pass to Mantua;
For then, I hope, thou wilt not keep him long,
For there it is, crack'd in a hundred shivers.
For there, they say, he daily doth frequent,
For these known evils, but to give me leave,
For they account his head upon the bridge.
For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.
For they do prank them in authority,
For they have pardons, being ask'd, as free
For they that were your enemies are his,
For thine own bowels, which do call thee sire,
For this affliction has a taste as sweet
For this alliance may so happy prove,
For this amongst the rest, was I ordain'd.
For this design. What course I mean to hold
For this is he that moves both wind and tide.
For this is thine and not King Henry's heirs'
For this new-married man approaching here,
For this night's watching.
For this one speech Lord Hastings well deserves
For this poor furniture and mean array.
For this reason, if you'll know,
For this time, all the rest depart away:
For this was of much length,--the vile conclusion
For this will out, and here I must not stay.
For this world frowns, and Edward's sun is clouded.
For this, be sure, to-night thou shalt have cramps,
For this, being smelt, with that part cheers each part;
For this, consorted with the citizens,
For those defects I have before rehearsed,
For thou are pleasant, gamesome, passing courteous,
For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.
For thou dost fear the soft and tender fork
For thou exist'st on many a thousand grains
For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell,
For thou must now know farther.
For thou set'st on thy wife.
For thou shalt know this strong right hand of mine
For thou wilt lie upon the wings of night
For though abundantly they lack discretion,
For though fond nature bids us an lament,
For though it have holp madmen to their wits,
For though mine enemy thou hast ever been,
For though they cannot greatly sting to hurt,
For though usurpers sway the rule awhile,
For though you lay here in this goodly chamber,
For through this laund anon the deer will come;
For thy complexion shifts to strange effects,
For thy conceit is soaking, will draw in
For thy great bounty, that not only givest
For time hath set a blot upon my pride.
For to a vision so apparent rumour
For to supply the places at the table,
For trust not him that hath once broken faith,--
For truth to o'er-peer. Rather than fool it so,
For truth, for duty, and for loyalty.
For vainer hours and tutors not so careful.
For violent fires soon burn out themselves;
For visiting your highness: my best train
For we are peremptory to dispatch
For we are soft as our complexions are,
For we have nothing else to ask, but that
For we to-morrow hold divided councils,
For we were subjects but while you were king.
For we will make for Ireland presently.
For well I wot that Henry is no soldier.
For well I wot ye blaze to burn them out
For well we know, no hand of blood and bone
For what I bid them do: for we bid this be done,
For what I have I need not to repeat;
For what before it was.
For what doth cherish weeds but gentle air?
For what hath broach'd this tumult but thy pride?
For what he did before Corioli, call him,
For what is he they follow?  truly, gentlemen,
For what is in this world but grief and woe?
For what offence?
For what reason, I beseech you?
For what thou hast not, still thou strivest to get,
For what, I pray thee?
For what, lieutenant? for well using me?
For what?
For when I was a king, my flatterers
For which I do discharge you of your office:
For which I must not plead, but that I am
For which I would not plead, but that I must;
For which my sinews shall be stretch'd upon him.
For which the heavens, taking angry note,
For which the people stir: if you will pass
For which you are a traitor to the people.
For which your honour and your faith is pawn'd;
For who is living, if those two are gone?
For who lived king, but I could dig his grave?
For whom, and not for Tybalt, Juliet pined.
For whose dear sake thou wast but lately dead;
For why, the senseless brands will sympathize
For wise men say it is the wisest course.
For with a band of thirty thousand men
For yesternight by Catesby was it brought me;
For yet his honour never heard a play--
For yet is hope of life and victory.
For you and I are past our dancing days:
For you have but mistook me all this while:
For you must know, we have with special soul
For you shall hop without my custom, sir:
For you, my noble Lord of Lancaster,
For you, the city, thus I turn my back:
For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.
For your best health and recreation.
For your broken shin.
For your physicians have expressly charged,
For's private friends: his answer to me was,
For, I am sure, you have your hands full all,
For, as the case now stands, it is a curse
For, being transported by my jealousies
For, by my soul, I'll ne'er acknowledge thee,
For, by the honour of my parents, I
For, by the way, I'll sort occasion,
For, by this light, whereby I see thy beauty,
For, by your leaves, you shall not stay alone
For, ere the six years that he hath to spend
For, hark you, Tybalt being slain so late,
For, knowing thee to be but young and light--
For, like an ass whose back with ingots bows,
For, look you, I may make the belly smile
For, lords, to-morrow is a busy day.
For, though before his face I speak the words
For, till I see them here, by doubtful fear
For, to yourself, what you do know, you must.
For, well I wot, thou hast thy mother's tongue.
For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.
For, were he, he had shown it in his looks.
Forbear awhile; we'll hear a little more.
Forbear it therefore; give your cause to heaven.
Forbear to sleep the nights, and fast the days;
Forbear your conference with the noble duke.
Forbid the sea for to obey the moon
Forbidden bandying in Verona streets:
Forbiddenly.
Forbids to dwell upon: yet remember this,
Force her hence.
Force me to keep you as a prisoner,
Forced by the tide to combat with the wind;
Forced to retire by fury of the wind:
Forerunning more requital.
Forewarn him that he use no scurrilous words in 's tunes.
Forget to pity him, lest thy pity prove
Forget, forgive; conclude and be agreed;
Forgetting any other home but this.
Forgive him, Angelo, that brought you home
Forgive me, cousin! Ah, dear Juliet,
Forgive my tyranny; but do not say
Forgiveness, horse! why do I rail on thee,
Forgot you! no, sir: I could not forget you, for I
Forsake the court: to do't, or no, is certain
Forslow no longer, make we hence amain.
Forspent with toil, as runners with a race,
Forswear Bianca and her love for ever.
Forswear themselves as often as they speak:
Forthlight the tilter, and brave Master Shooty the
Forthwith from Ludlow the young prince be fetch'd
Forthwith that Edward be pronounced a traitor,
Forthwith we'll send him hence to Brittany,
Fortunate mistress,--let my prophecy
Fortune and victory sit on thy helm!
Fortune speed us!
Forward, I pray, since we have come so far,
Foul devil, for God's sake, hence, and trouble us not;
Foul shame upon you! you have all moved mine.
Foul weather?
Foul wrinkled witch, what makest thou in my sight?
Fouler than heart can think thee, thou canst make
Found out the remedy. How would you be,
Found that the issue was not his begot;
Found truth in all but one: I, in twelve thousand, none.
Four lagging winters and four wanton springs
Four or five women once that tended me?
Fourth Citizen:
Fourth Citizen:
Fourth Citizen:
Fourth Messenger:
Framed in the prodigality of nature,
Frederick the great soldier who miscarried at sea?
Free speech and fearless I to thee allow.
Freed and enfranchised, not a party to
Frenchwoman.
Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.
Friar Lodowick to be a dishonest person?
Friar, not I I have been drinking hard all night,
Friar, thou knowest not the duke so well as I do:
Fridays. He's not past it yet, and I say to thee,
Friend,
Frighting her pale-faced villages with war
From Clifford's and Northumberland's pursuit:
From Dis's waggon! daffodils,
From Florence and must here deliver them.
From France?
From London by the king was I press'd forth;
From Ravenspurgh haven before the gates of York,
From Ravenspurgh to Cotswold will be found
From Richard's night to Bolingbroke's fair day.
From Rome all season'd office and to wind
From Rome.
From Scotland am I stol'n, even of pure love,
From Tamworth thither is but one day's march.
From all dishonesty he can: in this,
From all such devils, good Lord deliver us!
From all the impure blots and stains thereof;
From all the slaughters, wretch, that thou hast done!
From cold and empty veins, where no blood dwells;
From course required; or else thou must be counted
From east, west, north and south: be it concluded,
From every meaner man.
From fasting maids whose minds are dedicate
From flowery tenderness? If I must die,
From forth day's path and Titan's fiery wheels:
From forth the kennel of thy womb hath crept
From forth the ranks of many thousand French,
From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame,
From giving aid which late I promised.
From giving reins and spurs to my free speech;
From him that has most cause to grieve it should be,
From his true-meant design. Upon his place,
From love's weak childish bow she lives unharm'd.
From me do back receive the flour of all,
From me receive that natural competency
From me, the lord on't.
From mine own library with volumes that
From my Redeemer to redeem me hence;
From my own windows torn my household coat,
From my succession wipe me, father; I
From off my hands, here in the view of men
From off the battlements of yonder tower;
From off the gates of York fetch down the head,
From off the rock Tarpeian never more
From our faults, as faults from seeming, free!
From our free person she should be confined,
From out the fiery portal of the east,
From plume-pluck'd Richard; who with willing soul
From rascals worse than they.
From shelves and rocks that threaten us with wreck.
From slaves that apes would beat! Pluto and hell!
From some forefather grief; mine is not so,
From such a cause as fills mine eyes with tears
From such a filthy vice: say to thyself,
From sun to sun: there is my honour's pawn;
From that contented hap which I enjoy'd,
From the casque to the cushion, but commanding peace
From the corruption of abusing times,
From the dead blow of it. And you, enchantment.--
From the dead temples of this bloody wretch
From the most gracious regent of this land,
From the noise of our own drums.'
From the still-vex'd Bermoothes, there she's hid:
From thee, even from thy virtue!
From their abominable and beastly touches
From these old arms and legs, by the good gods,
From these our Henry lineally descends.
From thine own sister's shame? What should I think?
From this world's thraldom to the joys of heaven.
From this world-wearied flesh. Eyes, look your last!
From those that wish the downfall of our house!
From those you sent to the oracle are come
From thy admiring daughter took the spirits,
From too much liberty, my Lucio, liberty:
From twelve to seventy, and pouring war
From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.
From what a torment I did free thee?
From when this stream through muddy passages
From whence shall Warwick cut the sea to France,
From whence that tender spray did sweetly spring,
From whence this present day he is deliver'd?
From whence?
From where he should begin and end, but will
From where you do remain let paper show.
From which awaked, the truth of what we are
From which even here I slip my weary neck,
From which we would not have you warp. Call hither,
From whom we thought it meet to hide our love
From worthy Edward, King of Albion,
From your good queen.
From your kind aunt, Duchess of Burgundy,
From your own mouth, my lord, did I this deed.
Froth, I would not have you acquainted with
Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me
Full fathom five thy father lies;
Full half an hour.
Full of rose-water and bestrew'd with flowers,
Full of wise care is this your counsel, madam.
Full soon the canker death eats up that plant.
Full well hath Clifford play'd the orator,
Fully unfold. Thyself and thy belongings
Further I say and further will maintain
Further than seen and one infect another

Galen is but empiricutic, and, to this preservative,
Gallop apace, you fiery-footed steeds,
Gaoler:
Gaoler:

Gaoler:
Gardener, for telling me these news of woe,
Gardener:
Gardener:
Gardener:
Gardener:
Gardener:
Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave,
Gave hope thou wast in being, have preserved
Gave me my being and my father first,
Gazed each on other, and look'd deadly pale.
Gentle Mercutio, put thy rapier up.
Gentle and fair, your brother kindly greets you:
Gentle my liege,--
Gentle my lord, turn back.
Gentle son Edward, thou wilt stay with me?
Gentle spectators, that I now may be
Gentleman:
Gentleman:
Gentleman:
Gentleman:
Gentleman:
Gentleman:
Gentlemen and friends, I thank you for your pains:
Gentlemen, God save you. If I may be bold,
Gentlemen, content ye; I am resolved:
Gentlemen, for shame, forbear this outrage!
Gentlemen, forward to the bridal dinner:
Gentlemen, go, muster up your men,
Gentlemen, good den: a word with one of you.
Gentlemen, importune me no farther,
Gentlemen, that I may soon make good
Gentlemen, will you go muster men?
Gentlewoman:
Get me an iron crow, and bring it straight
Get thee to bed, and rest; for thou hast need.
Get undescried.
Get you gone.
Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends,
Get you hence, for I must go
Get you to bed; faith, You'll be sick to-morrow
Ghost of BUCKINGHAM:
Ghost of CLARENCE:
Ghost of GREY:
Ghost of HASTINGS:
Ghost of King Henry VI:
Ghost of LADY ANNE:
Ghost of Prince Edward:
Ghost of RIVERS:
Ghost of VAUGHAN:
Ghosts of young Princes:
Girl:
Girl:
Girl:
Give Richard leave to live till Richard die?
Give him deserved vexation. Let a guard
Give me Bianca for my patrimony.
Give me a case to put my visage in:
Give me a torch: I am not for this ambling;
Give me another horse: bind up my wounds.
Give me assurance with some friendly vow,
Give me excuse, good madam; I will obey you in every
Give me his gage: lions make leopards tame.
Give me mine own again; 'twere no good part
Give me my Romeo; and, when he shall die,
Give me my boots, I say.
Give me my boots, I say; saddle my horse.
Give me my sin again.
Give me no help in lamentation;
Give me some breath, some little pause, my lord
Give me some ink and paper in my tent
Give me some ink and paper.
Give me some present counsel, or, behold,
Give me that hand of yours to kiss.
Give me that mattock and the wrenching iron.
Give me the boy: I am glad you did not nurse him:
Give me the crown. Here, cousin, seize the crown;
Give me the glass, and therein will I read.
Give me the letter; I will look on it.
Give me the light: upon thy life, I charge thee,
Give me those flowers. Do as I bid thee, go.
Give me thy gold, if thou hast any gold:
Give me thy hand, Kate: I will unto Venice,
Give me thy hand.
Give me thy hand: Come.
Give me thy hand: I will swear to the prince thou
Give me thy hand; 'tis late: farewell; good night.
Give me thy torch, boy: hence, and stand aloof:
Give me, give me! O, tell not me of fear!
Give mine the benefit of seniory,
Give mistress Shore one gentle kiss the more.
Give rest to the minds of others, such as he
Give scandal to the blood o' the prince my son,
Give signal to the fight, and to it, lords!
Give some supportance to the bending twigs.
Give sorrow leave awhile to tutor me
Give the all-hail to thee and cry 'Be blest
Give up your body to such sweet uncleanness
Give up your keys.
Give us some seats. Come, cousin Angelo;
Give way there, and go on!
Give way to what's seen now! Sir, you yourself
Give you all greetings that a king, at friend,
Give you good morrow, sir.
Given Hydra here to choose an officer,
Given hostile strokes, and that not in the presence
Given to the fire, a moiety of my rest
Gives but the greater feeling to the worse:
Gives in your weakness strength unto your foe,
Gives me this instance: already he hath carried
Gives not the hawthorn-bush a sweeter shade
Gives signal, of a goodly day to-morrow.
Giving no ground unto the house of York,
Glad am I that your highness is so arm'd
Glad that you thus continue your resolve
Gladly, my lord.
Gloucester and Buckingham.
Gloucester,
Gloucester;
Gloves as sweet as damask roses;
Go I to fight: truth hath a quiet breast.
Go about it.
Go ask his name: if he be married.
Go bear this lance to Thomas, Duke of Norfolk.
Go before, nurse: commend me to thy lady;
Go do it instantly.
Go fetch him hither; let me look upon him.
Go fetch them hither: if they deny to come.
Go hence in debt: and therefore, like a cipher,
Go hence, to have more talk of these sad things;
Go hence; good night; and here stands all your state:
Go home to bed, and like the owl by day,
Go in to him, and fetch him out.
Go in, Bianca:
Go in: and tell my lady I am gone,
Go levy men, and make prepare for war;
Go make thyself like a nymph o' the sea: be subject
Go muster men; but, hear you, leave behind
Go not home.
Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow.
Go on, and fetch our horses back again.
Go on, go on
Go play, Mamillius; thou'rt an honest man.
Go ply thy needle; meddle not with her.
Go see this rumourer whipp'd. It cannot be
Go sleep, and hear us.
Go some of you and fetch a looking-glass.
Go take her hence, and marry her instantly.
Go tell the lords o' the city I am here:
Go then; and with a countenance as clear
Go thither; and, with unattainted eye,
Go thou away:
Go thou to Friar Penker; bid them both
Go thou to Juliet, help to deck up her;
Go thou, and fill another room in hell.
Go thou, and like an executioner,
Go to Flint castle: there I'll pine away;
Go to kennel, Pompey; go.
Go to my chamber; Put on clothes of mine.
Go to the feast, revel and domineer,
Go to the rude ribs of that ancient castle;
Go to them, with this bonnet in thy hand;
Go to, go to!
Go to, go to: no matter for the dish, sir.
Go to, go to;
Go to, sir; you weigh equally; a feather will turn
Go to, then.
Go to, we pardon thee: therefore, in brief,
Go to: what quality are they of? Elbow is your
Go to; I say you shall.
Go to; let that be mine:
Go waken Juliet, go and trim her up;
Go we to our tent:
Go where you will, the king shall be commanded;
Go whip him, 'fore the people's eyes:--his raising;
Go with me to clothe you as becomes you.
Go with me to the vault.
Go you before, and I will follow you.
Go you the next way with your findings. I'll go see
Go you to Juliet ere you go to bed,
Go you to him from me.
Go, Biondello, bid your mistress come to me.
Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight:
Go, Cleomenes;
Go, Lovel, with all speed to Doctor Shaw;
Go, after, after, cousin Buckingham.
Go, and be ruled: although I know thou hadst rather
Go, be gone.
Go, bear them hence; I will not hear them speak.
Go, bid thy master rise and come to me
Go, bind thou up yon dangling apricocks,
Go, by this token: rise, and lend thine ear:
Go, call my men, and let us straight to him;
Go, call the people:
Go, count thy way with sighs; I mine with groans.
Go, do our bidding; hence!
Go, fellow, get thee home, provide some carts
Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord;
Go, fool, and whom thou keep'st command.
Go, get thee gone, I say.
Go, get thee gone, thou false deluding slave,
Go, get thee hence, for I will not away.
Go, get thee to thy love, as was decreed,
Go, get you home, you fragments!
Go, get you to your house; be gone, away!
Go, girl, seek happy nights to happy days.
Go, girl; I cannot blame thee now to weep;
Go, go, dispatch.
Go, go, poor soul, I envy not thy glory
Go, go, up to the leads; the lord mayor knocks.
Go, hie thee, hie thee from this slaughter-house,
Go, hop me over every kennel home,
Go, masters, get you home; be not dismay'd:
Go, nurse, go with her: we'll to church to-morrow.
Go, play, boy, play: thy mother plays, and I
Go, rascals, go, and fetch my supper in.
Go, rate thy minions, proud insulting boy!
Go, say I sent thee forth to purchase honour
Go, see him out at gates, and follow him,
Go, signify as much, while here we march
Go, sirrah, take them to the buttery,
Go, sirrah, trudge about
Go, some of you convey him to the Tower.
Go, some of you, whoe'er you find attach.
Go, sound thy trumpet in the market-place;
Go, take it up unto thy master's use.
Go, tell the prince: run to the Capulets:
Go, then my mother, to thy daughter go
Go, then; for 'tis in vain
Go, tread the path that thou shalt ne'er return.
Go, trumpet, to the walls, and sound a parle.
Go, you cot-quean, go,
Go; I'll to dinner: hie you to the cell.
Go; away with her to prison!
God and Saint George! Richmond and victory!
God and our good cause fight upon our side;
God and our innocency defend and guard us!
God and your arms be praised, victorious friends,
God bless thee; and put meekness in thy mind,
God bless your grace with health and happy days!
God bless your grace! we see it, and will say it.
God for his Richard hath in heavenly pay
God for his mercy! what a tide of woes
God for his mercy, what treachery is here!
God forbid! Where's this girl? What, Juliet!
God forgive my sins, and pardon thee!
God gi' god-den. I pray, sir, can you read?
God give him joy!
God give us leisure for these rites of love!
God give your graces both
God grant him health! Did you confer with him?
God grant that some, less noble and less loyal,
God grant we never may have need of you!
God hold it, to your honour's good content!
God in heaven bless her!
God in thy good cause make thee prosperous!
God join'd my heart and Romeo's, thou our hands;
God keep all vows unbroke that swear to thee!
God keep me from false friends! but they were none.
God keep the prince from all the pack of you!
God keep you from them, and from such false friends!
God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!
God knows I had as lief be none as one.
God knows I will not do it, to the death.
God knows, in anguish, pain and agony.
God make your majesty joyful as you have been!
God pardon all oaths that are broke to me!
God pardon sin! wast thou with Rosaline?
God pardon them that are the cause of it!
God save King Harry, unking'd Richard says,
God save his majesty!
God save the king! Will no man say amen?
God save the king! although I be not he;
God save the mark!--here on his manly breast:
God save you, gentlemen!
God save you, sir!

God save your lordship!

God's bread! it makes me mad:

God's wrong is most of all.
