Thomas the Earl of Surrey, and himself,
Thorough my rust! and how his pity
Those are pearls that were his eyes:
Those are they
Those centuries to our aid: the rest will serve
Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,
Those gracious words revive my drooping thoughts
Those many had not dared to do that evil,
Those men you talk of came into my mind.
Those of your fact are so--so past all truth:
Those uncles which you want were dangerous;
Those whose great power must try him; even this,
Those will I muster up: and thou, son Clarence,
Thou and Oxford, with five thousand men,
Thou and my bosom henceforth shall be twain.
Thou and these woes were all for Rosaline:
Thou and thy brother both shall buy this treason
Thou art Hermione; or rather, thou art she
Thou art a banish'd man, and here art come
Thou art a fool: if Echo were as fleet,
Thou art a lord, and nothing but a lord:
Thou art a traitor and a miscreant,
Thou art a widow, and thou hast some children;
Thou art a widow; yet thou art a mother,
Thou art always figuring diseases in me; but thou
Thou art as opposite to every good
Thou art deceived: 'tis not thy southern power,
Thou art inclined to sleep; 'tis a good dulness,
Thou art like one of those fellows that when he
Thou art my warrior;
Thou art no Atlas for so great a weight:
Thou art not conquer'd; beauty's ensign yet
Thou art not here: murder is thy alms-deed;
Thou art not honest; and the gods will plague thee,
Thou art perfect then, our ship hath touch'd upon
Thou art poor'st of all; then shortly art thou mine.
Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend
Thou art the cause, and most accursed effect.
Thou art the first knave that e'er madest a duke.
Thou art their soldier, and being bred in broils
Thou art thence banish'd, we would muster all
Thou art thyself, though not a Montague.
Thou art too noble to conserve a life
Thou art up-roused by some distemperature;
Thou bear's thy heavy riches but a journey,
Thou bear'st my life off hence: let us avoid.
Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood!
Thou cacodemon! there thy kingdom is.
Thou call'dst me king.
Thou call'dst me up at midnight to fetch dew
Thou camest here to complain.
Thou camest on earth to make the earth my hell.
Thou camest--
Thou canst help time to furrow me with age,
Thou canst not frown, thou canst not look askance,
Thou canst not speak of that thou dost not feel:
Thou canst not speak too much; I have deserved
Thou canst not, son; it is impossible.
Thou chid'st me oft for loving Rosaline.
Thou chidest me well: proud Bolingbroke, I come
Thou concludest like the sanctimonious pirate, that
Thou counterfeit'st a bark, a sea, a wind;
Thou cutt'st my head off with a golden axe,
Thou darest not this and that to prove more fortunes
Thou darest not, coward, live to see that day.
Thou dearest Perdita,
Thou desirest me to stop in my tale against the hair.
Thou desperate pilot, now at once run on
Thou detestable maw, thou womb of death,
Thou didst love York, and I am son to York.
Thou didst prevent me; I had peopled else
Thou didst receive the holy sacrament,
Thou didst speak but well
Thou didst usurp my place, and dost thou not
Thou dost advise me
Thou dost beguile me! Was this face the face
Thou dost confirm his happiness for ever.
Thou dost make possible things not so held,
Thou dost, and think'st it much to tread the ooze
Thou dotard! thou art woman-tired, unroosted
Thou draw not on thy danger and dishonour;
Thou drown the sad remembrance of those wrongs
Thou earth, thou! speak.
Thou elvish-mark'd, abortive, rooting hog!
Thou factious Duke of York, descend my throne,
Thou flea, thou nit, thou winter-cricket thou!
Thou fond mad man, hear me but speak a word.
Thou fond mad woman,
Thou foolish friar, and thou pernicious woman,
Thou frantic woman, what dost thou make here?
Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold
Thou hadst a Clarence too, and Richard kill'd him.
Thou hadst a Richard, till a Richard killed him;
Thou hadst an Edward, till a Richard kill'd him;
Thou hadst but power over his mortal body,
Thou hadst not lived to kill a son of mine.
Thou hadst, and more, Miranda. But how is it
Thou hast a grim appearance, and thy face
Thou hast a lady far more beautiful
Thou hast affected the fine strains of honour,
Thou hast amazed me: by my holy order,
Thou hast done a deed whereat valour will weep.
Thou hast faced many things.
Thou hast hit it: come, sit on me.
Thou hast howl'd away twelve winters.
Thou hast most kindly hit it.
Thou hast neither heat, affection, limb, nor beauty,
Thou hast not done before.
Thou hast one son; for his sake pity me,
Thou hast said enough.
Thou hast spoke too much already: get thee gone.
Thou hast sworn it more to me:
Thou hast sworn my love to be.
Thou hast the strength of will to slay thyself,
Thou hast undone thyself, thy son and me;
Thou hast years upon thee; and thou art too full
Thou hast. Where was she born? speak; tell me.
Thou kill'st me in his life; giving him breath,
Thou know'st my daughter's of a pretty age.
Thou know'st my lodging: get me ink and paper,
Thou know'st our reasons urged upon the way;
Thou know'st the mask of night is on my face,
Thou know'st, was banish'd: for one thing she did
Thou let'st thy fortune sleep--die, rather; wink'st
Thou liest, malignant thing! Hast thou forgot
Thou liest: his father is come from Padua and here
Thou loathed issue of thy father's loins!
Thou lovest me not; for, brother, if thou didst,
Thou madst thine enemies shake, as if the world
Thou map of honour, thou King Richard's tomb,
Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed!
Thou mayst co-join with something; and thou dost,
Thou mayst prove false; at lovers' perjuries
Thou mightst be freed.
Thou most lying slave,
Thou must be made immortal. Where's Barnardine?
Thou must be married to no man but me;
Thou noble thing! more dances my rapt heart
Thou pitied'st Rutland; I will pity thee.
Thou poisonous slave, got by the devil himself
Thou pout'st upon thy fortune and thy love:
Thou rag of honour! thou detested--
Thou rascal, that art worst in blood to run,
Thou rather with thy sharp and sulphurous bolt
Thou seest what's past, go fear thy king withal.
Thou setter up and plucker down of kings,
Thou shalt be borne to that same ancient vault
Thou shalt be free
Thou shalt be logger-head. Good faith, 'tis day:
Thou shalt be master, Tranio, in my stead,
Thou shalt continue two and forty hours,
Thou shalt not do't.
Thou shalt not stir a foot to seek a foe.
Thou sheer, immaculate and silver fountain,
Thou shouldst a husband take by my consent,
Thou shouldst not scape me here.
Thou show'st a noble vessel: what's thy name?
Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life,
Thou sing'st sweet music. Hark, come hither, Tyrrel
Thou slander of thy mother's heavy womb!
Thou slewest my husband Henry in the Tower,
Thou smiling while he knit his angry brows:
Thou sober-suited matron, all in black,
Thou speak'st truth.
Thou stern, obdurate, flinty, rough, remorseless.
Thou strokedst me and madest much of me, wouldst give me
Thou talk'st of nothing.
Thou that so stoutly hast resisted me,
Thou that wast seal'd in thy nativity
Thou think'st there is no more such shapes as he,
Thou to me thy secrets tell.
Thou toad, thou toad, where is thy brother Clarence?
Thou troublest me; am not in the vein.
Thou villain Capulet,--Hold me not, let me go.
Thou want'st a rough pash and the shoots that I have,
Thou wast never with me for any thing when thou wast
Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind.
Thou wast that did preserve me. Thou didst smile.
Thou wast the prettiest babe that e'er I nursed:
Thou wilt amend thy life?
Thou wilt be taken. Stay awhile! Stand up;
Thou wilt fall backward when thou comest to age;
Thou wilt fall backward when thou hast more wit;
Thou wilt perform my bidding.
Thou wilt prove his. Take him to prison, officer:
Thou wilt revolt, and fly to him, I fear.
Thou worthiest Marcius!
Thou wouldst be fee'd, I see, to make me sport:
Thou wouldst else have made thy tale large.
Thou wouldst have left thy dearest heart-blood there,
Thou wouldst have poison'd good Camillo's honour,
Thou wretch, despite o'erwhelm thee!
Thou wrong'st it, more than tears, with that report.
Thou yard, three-quarters, half-yard, quarter, nail!
Thou'ldst not believe thy deeds: but I'll report it
Thou'ldst thank me but a little for my counsel:
Thou'rt a tall fellow: hold thee that to drink.
Thou'rt i' the right, girl; more o, that.
Thou'rt tired, then, in a word, I also am
Thou, Richard, shalt to the Duke of Norfolk,
Thou, being a king, blest with a goodly son,
Thou, brother Montague, in Buckingham,
Thou, it seems, that calls for company to
Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.
Thou, old Adam's likeness, set to dress this garden,
Thou, traitor, hast set on thy wife to this.
Thou, wretched boy, that didst consort him here,
Though 'twere to buy a world of happy days,
Though Fortune, visible an enemy,
Though I am satisfied and need no more
Though I could wish
Though I show'd sourly to him, once more offer'd
Though Marcius earned them not, and all his faults
Though Paris came in hope to speed alone.
Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear,
Though all the world's vastidity you had,
Though angel on the outward side!
Though banish'd, yet a trueborn Englishman.
Though bearing misery, I desire my life
Though calved i' the porch o' the Capitol--
Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.
Though destiny say no. Be merry, gentle;
Though every drop of water swear against it
Though far more cause, yet much less spirit to curse
Though first in question, is thy secondary.
Though fortune's malice overthrow my state,
Though full of our displeasure, yet we free thee
Though he be blunt, I know him passing wise;
Though he be merry, yet withal he's honest.
Though he divide the realm and give thee half,
Though he does bear some signs of me, yet you
Though he hath fallen by prompture of the blood,
Though heaven cannot: O Romeo, Romeo!
Though in Rome litter'd--not Romans--as they are not,
Though in some part enforced to digress;
Though little fire grows great with little wind,
Though news be sad, yet tell them merrily;
Though not for Rome itself.
Though rebels wound thee with their horses' hoofs:
Though some of you with Pilate wash your hands
Though sometimes you do blench from this to that,
Though thanks to all, must I select
Though the nature of our quarrel yet never brooked
Though there the people had more absolute power,
Though therein you can never be too noble,
Though they themselves did suffer by't, behold
Though they would swear down each particular saint,
Though this be all, do not so quickly go;
Though this island seem to be desert,--
Though thou didst learn, had that in't which
Though thou speak'st truth,
Though we have spent our harvest of this king,
Though yet she speak not. Mark a little while.
Though you are old enough to be my heir.
Though you perceive me not how I give line.
Though you were born in Rome:' his bloody brow
Though you would seek to unsphere the
Thoughts high for one so tender, cleft the heart
Thoughts tending to ambition, they do plot
Thoughts tending to content flatter themselves
Thoughts that would thick my blood.
Three Dukes of Somerset, threefold renown'd
Three Judases, each one thrice worse than Judas!
Three civil brawls, bred of an airy word,
Three crabbed months had sour'd themselves to death,
Three glorious suns, each one a perfect sun;
Three or four miles about, else had I, sir,
Three parts of that receipt I had for Calais
Three times did Richard make a lane to me.
Three times to-day my foot-cloth horse did stumble,
Three words, dear Romeo, and good night indeed.
Three, my most gracious lord.
Three, they say: but 'tis thought of every one
Threw dust and rubbish on King Richard's head.
Threw off his spirit, his appetite, his sleep,
Thrice noble lord, let me entreat of you
Throng many doubtful hollow-hearted friends,
Throng our large temples with the shows of peace,
Throng to the bar, crying all, Guilty! guilty!
Through 'tis a saying, sir, not due to me.
Through all the signories it was the first
Through brazen trumpet send the breath of parley
Through casements darted their desiring eyes
Through fair Verona; find those persons out
Through it do well, I do not relish well
Through lovers' brains, and then they dream of love;
Through the false passage of thy throat, thou liest.
Throw death upon thy sovereign's enemies.
Throw down, my son, the Duke of Norfolk's gage.
Throw over her the veil of infamy:
Throw up thine eye! see, see what showers arise,
Throw your mistemper'd weapons to the ground,
Thrusts forth his horns again into the world;
Thursday is near; lay hand on heart, advise:
Thus I conceive by him.
Thus I enforce thy rotten jaws to open,
Thus both are gone with conscience and remorse;
Thus by Apollo's great divine seal'd up,
Thus can the demigod Authority
Thus do I hope to shake King Henry's head.
Thus do I leave thee. Come, son, let's away;
Thus doth he force the swords of wicked men
Thus far into the bowels of the land
Thus far our fortune keeps an upward course,
Thus from my lips, by yours, my sin is purged.
Thus give I mine, and thus take I thy heart.
Thus hath the course of justice wheel'd about,
Thus have I politicly begun my reign,
Thus have we swept suspicion from our seat
Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.
Thus high at least, although your knee be low.
Thus high, by thy advice
Thus in plain terms: your father hath consented
Thus it is: the Volsces have an army forth; against
Thus plated in habiliments of war,
Thus play I in one person many people,
Thus stands it with me: upon a true contract
Thus stands the case: you know our king, my brother,
Thus strangers may be hailed and abused: O
Thus thrust disorderly into my hands,
Thus to have said,
Thus to retort your manifest appeal,
Thus we set on, Camillo, to the sea-side.
Thus will I drown your exclamations.
Thus wisdom wishes to appear most bright
Thus yields the cedar to the axe's edge,
Thus, like the formal vice, Iniquity,
Thus, what with the war, what with the sweat, what
Thus, with his speechless hand: what he would do,
Thy Clarence he is dead that kill'd my Edward;
Thy Edward he is dead, that stabb'd my Edward:
Thy age confirm'd, proud, subdued, bloody,
Thy balm wash'd off wherewith thou wast anointed:
Thy beauty hath made me effeminate
Thy beauty hath, and made them blind with weeping.
Thy beauty, that doth make me like thee well,
Thy brat hath been cast out, like to itself,
Thy broken faith hath made a prey for worms.
Thy brother Edward, and thyself the sea
Thy brother being carelessly encamp'd,
Thy brother's blood the thirsty earth hath drunk,
Thy brother's love, our duty, and thy fault,
Thy buried fear: herein all breathless lies
Thy burning car never had scorch'd the earth!
Thy by-gone fooleries were but spices of it.
Thy country's strength and weakness,--thine own ways;
Thy dangerous stoutness, for I mock at death
Thy dear love sworn but hollow perjury,
Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thyself;
Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land
Thy deed, inhuman and unnatural,
Thy drugs are quick. Thus with a kiss I die.
Thy exercise hath been too violent for
Thy face is mine, and thou hast slander'd it.
Thy father bears the type of King of Naples,
Thy father hath.
Thy father slew my father; therefore, die.
Thy father was a traitor to the crown.
Thy father was the Duke of Milan and
Thy father was, as thou art, Duke of York;
Thy father! O villain! he is a sailmaker in Bergamo.
Thy father's court? for thou shalt hear that I,
Thy father's ground.
Thy father, Minos, that denied our course;
Thy father, or thy mother, nay, or both,
Thy fault our law calls death; but the kind prince,
Thy friend no less
Thy friends are fled to wait upon thy foes,
Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest,
Thy garments are not spotted with our blood,
Thy gown? why, ay: come, tailor, let us see't.
Thy grandfather, Roger Mortimer, Earl of March:
Thy grief is but thy absence for a time.
Thy head is as fun of quarrels as an egg is full of
Thy head, all indirectly, gave direction:
Thy head, thy sovereign; one that cares for thee,
Thy honour, state and seat is due to me.
Thy hounds shall make the welkin answer them
Thy husband in thy bosom there lies dead;
Thy husband is thy lord, thy life, thy keeper,
Thy kingly doom and sentence of his pride.
Thy kinsman and thy friends, I'll have more lives
Thy knee bussing the stones--for in such business
Thy life answer!
Thy life hath that dishonour'd.
Thy lips are warm.
Thy love did read by rote and could not spell.
Thy lying tongue both numbers, I would say
Thy mother felt more than a mother's pain,
Thy mother rather feel thy pride than fear
Thy mother was a piece of virtue, and
Thy mother's name is ominous to children.
Thy murderous falchion smoking in his blood;
Thy nerves are in their infancy again
Thy news?
Thy noble shape is but a form of wax,
Thy old groans ring yet in my ancient ears;
Thy other Edward dead, to quit my Edward;
Thy overflow of good converts to bad,
Thy pains, Fitzwater, shall not be forgot;
Thy penitent reform'd: but we have been
Thy place is fill'd, thy sceptre wrung from thee,
Thy prime of manhood daring, bold, and venturous,
Thy purpose marriage, send me word to-morrow,
Thy school-days frightful, desperate, wild, and furious,
Thy sin's not accidental, but a trade.
Thy slanders I forgive; and therewithal
Thy sly conveyance and thy lord's false love;
Thy son I kill'd for his presumption.
Thy son by this hath married. Wonder not,
Thy son is banish'd upon good advice,
Thy sorrow in my breast. Come, ladies, go,
Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--
Thy sun sets weeping in the lowly west,
Thy tears are salter than a younger man's,
Thy tears are womanish; thy wild acts denote
Thy tears would wash this cold congealed blood
Thy tempest-tossed body. How now, wife!
Thy thoughts with nobleness; that thou mayst prove
Thy valiantness was mine, thou suck'dst it from me,
Thy virtues spoke of, and thy beauty sounded,
Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
Thy wife Paulina more.' And so, with shrieks
Thy wife and children's blood. For myself, son,
Thy wit is a very bitter sweeting; it is a most
Thy wit, that ornament to shape and love,
Thy woes will make them sharp, and pierce like mine.
Thy womb let loose, to chase us to our graves.
Thy word is current with him for my death,
Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.
Thyself a queen, for me that was a queen,
Thyself thyself misusest.
Thyself upon thy virtues, they on thee.
Thyself, forsooth, hereafter theirs, so far
Tiber in't; said to be something imperfect in
Tickle the senseless rushes with their heels,
Tickled with good success, disdains the shadow
Tickling a parson's nose as a' lies asleep,
Tidings, as swiftly as the posts could run,
Tie leaden pounds to's heels. Proceed by process;
Ties up my tongue, and will not let me speak.
Till Bolingbroke have pardon'd thee. Away, be gone!
Till George be pack'd with post-horse up to heaven.
Till I be brought to such a silly pass!
Till I can find occasion of revenge.
Till I conveniently could send to Romeo:
Till I have told this slander of his blood,
Till Katharina the curst have got a husband.
Till Norfolk be repeal'd: repeal'd he shall be,
Till Warwick or himself be quite suppress'd.
Till either death hath closed these eyes of mine
Till he be dieted to my request,
Till he did look on me: since it is so,
Till he had forged himself a name o' the fire
Till his lost child be found? which that it shall,
Till holy church incorporate two in one.
Till it o'er-run the stew; laws for all faults,
Till it was whetted on thy stone-hard heart,
Till one can do no more.
Till our King Henry had shook hands with death.
Till she had laid it and conjured it down;
Till she herself confess it.
Till storms be past of civil enmity.
Till that my nails were anchor'd in thine eyes;
Till the prince came, who parted either part.
Till then fair hope must hinder life's decay.
Till then, 'tis wisdom to conceal our meaning.
Till then, adieu; and keep this holy kiss.
Till they have fretted us a pair of graves
Till thou give joy; until thou bid me joy,
Till thou shalt know the reason of my love:
Till thou the lie-giver and that lie do lie
Till time had made them for us. But it chances
Till time lend friends and friends their helpful swords.
Till twice five summers have enrich'd our fields
Till we assign you to your days of trial.
Till we can clear these ambiguities,
Till we meet Warwick with his foreign power.
Till you did make him misinterpret me,
Till you have done your business in the city:
Till you have heard me in my true complaint
Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.
Time out o' mind the fairies' coachmakers.
Time-pleasers, flatterers, foes to nobleness.
Time:
Tincture or lustre in her lip, her eye,
Tire on the flesh of me and of my son!
Titus Lartius writes, they fought together, but
To Bolingbroke are we sworn subjects now,
To Bolingbroke.
To Bona, sister to the King of France.
To Brecknock, while my fearful head is on!
To Bristol castle, which they say is held
To Coriolanus come all joy and honour!
To County Paris, to prepare him up
To County Paris: then comes she to me,
To Edward, but not to the English king.
To England's king in lawful marriage.
To God of heaven, King Richard and to me;
To God, his sovereign and to him disloyal;
To God, my king and my succeeding issue,
To God, the widow's champion and defence.
To Henry Bolingbroke.
To Henry's body, and supply his place;
To Italy; and there at Venice gave
To Juliet's grave; for there must I use thee.
To Julius Caesar's ill-erected tower,
To Lammas-tide?
To London, all in post; and, as I guess,
To Lynn, my lord,
To Mantua, with my letters to thy lord.
To Marcius shall be honours, though indeed
To Oxford, or where'er these traitors are:
To Richmond, in those parts beyond the sea
To Rome of our success. You, Titus Lartius,
To Salisbury; the rest march on with me.
To Stanley's regiment; bid him bring his power
To Valentinus, Rowland, and to Crassus,
To a dear friend of the good Duke of York's,
To a determined scope.
To a mother's part belongs. He turns away:
To accuse this worthy man, but, in foul mouth
To act her earthy and abhorr'd commands,
To all his lands and signories: when he's return'd,
To ally my rages and revenges with
To alter this, for counsel is but vain.
To an impatient child that hath new robes
To an infected jelly and my name
To answer 'I'll not wed; I cannot love,
To answer all the city.
To answer mildly; for they are prepared
To answer other business. Shrug'st thou, malice?
To answer that, I should confess to you.
To answer thy best pleasure; be't to fly,
To answer twenty thousand such as you.
To answer us.
To appoint myself in this vexation, sully
To aspire unto the crown and reign as king.
To avoid the carping censures of the world.
To bandy word for word and frown for frown;
To banish him that struck more blows for Rome
To banish your defenders; till at length
To bar my master's heirs in true descent,
To base declension and loathed bigamy
To bate me a full year.
To bathe in fiery floods, or to reside
To be a make-peace shall become my age:
To be a virtuous and well-govern'd youth:
To be acknowledged: thou a sceptre's heir,
To be by oath enjoin'd to this. Farewell!
To be consorted with the humorous night:
To be discover'd, that can do me good?
To be full like me: yet they say we are
To be full quit of those my banishers,
To be her men and wear her livery:
To be imprison'd in the viewless winds,
To be inclined my way!
To be no better than a homely swain;
To be o'erpower'd; and wilt thou, pupil-like,
To be or none or little; though a devil
To be received plain, I'll speak more gross:
To be revenged on Rivers, Vaughan, Grey:
To be revenged on him that loveth you.
To be revenged on him that slew my husband.
To be set high in place, we did commend
To be so bouted in this royal presence?
To be so rid o' the business.
To be spoke to but by the recorder.
To be the aim of every dangerous shot,
To be the father unto many sons.
To be thus taunted, scorn'd, and baited at:
To be thy nurses! Wolves and bears, they say
To be to thee this night a torch-bearer,
To be your comforter when he is gone.
To be your prisoner should import offending;
To bear a poison, I would temper it;
To bear her burthen, whether I will or no,
To bear his image and renew his glories!
To bear the golden yoke of sovereignty,
To bear the matter thus; mere weakness. If
To bear the tidings of calamity.
To beautify him, only lacks a cover:
To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear,
To beg of thee, it is my more dishonour
To bend the fatal instruments of war
To better purpose.
To better vantage.
To bid me trudge:
To bid the father wipe his eyes withal,
To bide upon't, thou art not honest, or,
To bitterest enmity: so, fellest foes,
To blaze your marriage, reconcile your friends,
To blazon it, then sweeten with thy breath
To bless the bed of majesty again
To bloody thoughts and to revenge, I chose
To blot out me, and put his own son in.
To both their deaths thou shalt be accessary.
To brag unto them, thus I did, and thus;
To break the heart of generosity,
To breakfast once forth of my company.
To breathe such vows as lovers use to swear;
To breathe the abundant dolour of the heart.
To breathe this news; yet what I say is true.
To bring false generations: they are co-heirs;
To bring the roof to the foundation,
To bring this tidings to the bloody king.
To bring you thus together, 'tis no sin,
To bury mine intents, but also to effect
To buy and sell with groats, to show bare heads
To buy apparel 'gainst the wedding-day.
To buy you a better husband.
To call hers exquisite, in question more:
To call him villain? and then to glance from him
To call me to your senate, I'll deliver
To call them woollen vassals, things created
To call upon him.
To carve out dials quaintly, point by point,
To cast thy wandering eyes on every stale,
To catch my death with jaunting up and down!
To cease this civil war, and, whilst I live,
To cease thy suit, and leave me to my grief:
To change blows with thee for our day of doom.
To cheque time broke in a disorder'd string;
To chide at your extremes it not becomes me:
To chide my fortune, and torment myself?
To choke it in the utterance. So our virtues
To choose you a queen: she shall not be so young
To cleave a heart in twain.
To closeness and the bettering of my mind
To comb your noddle with a three-legg'd stool
To come at first when he doth send for her,
To come at traitors' calls and do them grace.
To come to Padua. Know you not the cause?
To come to me forthwith.
To comfort Edward with our company.
To comfort thee, though thou art banished.
To comfort you: I wot well where he is.
To counsel me to make my peace with God,
To counterfeit oppression of such grief
To credit his own lie, he did believe
To crop at once a too long wither'd flower.
To cross me from the golden time I look for!
To cross my obsequies and true love's rite?
To cry to the sea that roar'd to us, to sigh
To curb the will of the nobility:
To cut off those that have offended him.
To dark dishonour's use thou shalt not have.
To dash our late decree in parliament
To deck his fortune with his virtuous deeds:
To deck our soldiers for these Irish wars.
To die for't!
To die upon the bed my father died,
To die when I desire.
To dim his glory and to stain the track
To disproportion me in every part,
To do a thing, where I the issue doubted,
To do him good?
To do in slander. And to behold his sway,
To do me business in the veins o' the earth
To do myself this wrong: till, at the last,
To do that office of thine own good will
To do them good, I would sustain some harm.
To do this deed will hate you for the deed.
To do this ruthless piece of butchery,
To do what service am I sent for hither?
To doom the offenders, whatsoever they be
To draw him from his holy exercise.
To draw the brats of Clarence out of sight;
To draw with idle spiders' strings
To dress thy meat myself and bring it thee:
To drive away the heavy thought of care?
To dwell in solemn shades of endless night.
To ear the land that hath some hope to grow,
To ease his breast with panting.
To effect this marriage, so it please my lord.
To entail him and his heirs unto the crown,
To enter human hearing, from Argier,
To enter in the thoughts of desperate men!
To enter our Rome gates: i' the people's name,
To enter publicly: him I'll desire
To entertain these fair well-spoken days,
To entreat your majesty to visit him.
To every article.
To every eyeball else. Go take this shape
To excel the golden age.
To execute the charge my father gave me
To execute the like upon thyself;
To execute the noble duke at Calais.
To execution and the hand of death.
To expel him thence. I think he'll be to Rome
To extol what it hath done.
To fail in the disposing of those chances
To fair Bianca, so beloved of me.
To faithful service of your majesty.
To fear the foe, since fear oppresseth strength,
To feast and sport us at thy father's house.
To feed my humour, wish thyself no harm.
To feed my innocent people.
To fetch a ladder, by the which your love
To fight against that bloody homicide.
To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.
To fight on Edward's party for the crown;
To fight with Glendower and his complices:
To find out right with wrong, it may not be;
To find out this abuse, whence 'tis derived.
To find this practise out.
To fine the faults whose fine stands in record,
To flatter Henry and forsake thy brother!
To fleer and scorn at our solemnity?
To fly the boar before the boar pursues,
To follow as it draws! I'll to my brother:
To follow this fair corse unto her grave:
To foreign passages, and in the end,
To fortune's yoke, but let thy dauntless mind
To free King Henry from imprisonment
To fright me with your sprites; you're powerful at it.
To fright the souls of fearful adversaries,
To fright them, ere destroy. But come in:
To frustrate both his oath and what beside
To gather in some debts, my son Lucentio
To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?
To get her cunning schoolmasters to instruct her?
To get slips of them.
To give him annual tribute, do him homage,
To give me secret harbour, hath a purpose
To give mine enemy a lasting wink;
To give my hand opposed against my heart
To give my poor host freedom.
To give or to forgive; but when we have stuff'd
To give the heir and daughter of Lord Scales
To give thee all, and in his waning age
To give you over at this first encounter,
To give your censures in this weighty business?
To gnaw their garners. Worshipful mutiners,
To go along with us; for as we think,
To go with Paris to Saint Peter's Church,
To go with us unto the officers.
To gratify his noble service that
To gratulate the gentle princes there.
To greet a man not worth her pains, much less
To greet him and to give him comforts. Sir,
To greet mine own land with my wishful sight.
To grim Necessity, and he and I
To grubs and eyeless skulls? as I discern,
To harder bosoms! Looking on the lines
To haste thus fast, to find us unprovided.
To have a giant's strength; but it is tyrannous
To have a temple built you: all the swords
To have a worthy feeding: but I have it
To have free speech with you; and it concerns me
To have her honour true than your suspicion,
To have her match'd: and having now provided
To have him kill a king: poor trespasses,
To have him match'd; and if you please to like
To have him suddenly convey'd away.
To have it added to the faults of mine,
To have my praise for this, perform a part
To have no screen between this part he play'd
To have nor eyes nor ears nor thought, then say
To have some conference with your grace alone.
To have the heir of the Lord Hungerford.
To have them recompensed as thought on.
To have what we would have, we speak not what we mean:
To have you royally appointed as if
To have't with saying 'Good morrow.'
To hear Cominius speak, I'll keep at home.
To hear Cominius speak?
To hear and see her plaints, her brinish tears.
To hear good counsel: O, what learning is!
To hear her prayers for them, as now for us
To hear him named, and cannot come to him.
To hear my nothings monster'd.
To hear the lamentations of Poor Anne,
To hear the piteous moan that Rutland made
To hear thee speak of Naples. He does hear me;
To hear themselves remember'd.
To hear true shrift. Come, madam, let's away.
To help Cominius.
To help King Edward in his time of storm,
To help him to his grave immediately!
To help me after? I will kiss thy lips;
To help me sort such needful ornaments
To help our fielded friends! Come, blow thy blast.
To help thee curse that poisonous bunchback'd toad.
To help to take her from her borrow'd grave,
To her I go, a jolly thriving wooer.
To her acceptance; you have let him go
To her allowing husband!
To her unhappy brother Claudio?
To her, Kate!
To her, widow!
To hide your doings; and to silence that,
To high promotions and great dignity:
To him forthwith in holy wedlock bands.
To him had left it solely.
To him or our authorities. For an end,
To him that hath more cause to be a mourner,
To him, and to his substitutes.
To his concupiscible intemperate lust,
To his most royal person, hither come
To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.
To his surname Coriolanus 'longs more pride
To hold my stirrup nor to take my horse!
To hold thine own and leave thine own with him.
To honour me as thy king and sovereign,
To hopeless restitution, so he might
To horse, to horse! urge doubts to them that fear.
To house or housekeeping: then, at my farm
To hurl upon their heads that break his law.
To imitate the graces of the gods;
To insinuate, flatter, bow, and bend my limbs:
To instruct her fully in those sciences,
To jump a body with a dangerous physic
To justify this worthy nobleman,
To keep him safely till his day of trial.
To keep that oath were more impiety
To keep the oath that we administer:
To keep them back that come to succor you:
To keep your great pretences veil'd till when
To kill the king at Oxford.
To kindle their dry stubble; and their blaze
To kings that fear their subjects' treachery?
To know our further pleasure in this case,
To know the cause why music was ordain'd!
To know, when two authorities are up,
To lay aside life-harming heaviness
To lay one in, another out to have.
To lay upon the damn'd, which Sycorax
To learn the order of my fingering,
To leave this keen encounter of our wits,
To lengthen out the worst that must be spoken:
To let him slip at will.
To let him there a month behind the gest
To let me see them and to make me know
To let thy tongue detect thy base-born heart?
To lie close by his honest bones: but now
To lie discolour'd by this place of peace?
To lie in cold obstruction and to rot;
To lie that way thou go'st, not whence thou comest:
To lift shrewd steel against our golden crown,
To lingering sufferance. Answer me to-morrow,
To link with him that were not lawful chosen.
To live an unstain'd wife to my sweet love.
To load my she with knacks: I would have ransack'd
To lock it in the wards of covert bosom,
To lock up honesty and honour from
To look into the bottom of my place:
To look so poorly and to speak so fair?
To look that way thou wert.
To look upon my sometimes royal master's face.
To lose his head; condemn'd by Angelo:
To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts
To loss and what may follow! Weep I cannot,
To lure this tassel-gentle back again!
To make William Lord Hastings of our mind,
To make a bloody supper in the Tower.
To make a bondmaid and a slave of me;
To make a dulcet and a heavenly sound;
To make a false one.
To make a perfect woman, she you kill'd
To make a second fall of cursed man?
To make a shambles of the parliament-house!
To make a stale of me amongst these mates?
To make amends, Ill give it to your daughter.
To make an act of tragic violence:
To make an envious mountain on my back,
To make bad good, and good provoke to harm.
To make coals cheap,--a noble memory!
To make confession and to be absolved.
To make die with a restorative.
To make her come and know her keeper's call,
To make her heavenly comforts of despair,
To make her speak as move.
To make him an example. All hope is gone,
To make him worthy whose offence subdues him
To make my end too sudden: learn, good soul,
To make prescription for a kingdom's worth.
To make the base earth proud with kissing it:
To make the perfect period of this peace.
To make the truth appear where it seems hid,
To make thee consul.
To make this shameless callet know herself.
To make thy riches pleasant. What's yet in this
To make you garlands of, and my sweet friend,
To mangle me with that word 'banished'?
To marry Paris: Wednesday is to-morrow:
To me a break-neck. Happy star, reign now!
To me can life be no commodity:
To me for justice and rough chastisement;
To me inveterate, hearkens my brother's suit;
To me or my swift passage, that I slide
To me she's married, not unto my clothes:
To me the difference forges dread; your greatness
To meet anon, upon your approbation.
To meet at London London's king in woe.
To meet her new-beloved any where:
To meet me at the consecrated fount
To meet with joy in sweet Jerusalem.
To meet you at the Tower and welcome you.
To meet you on the way, and welcome you.
To melt myself away in water-drops!
To melt the city leads upon your pates,
To men in joy; but grief makes one hour ten.
To men of middle age. You're very welcome.
To mend her kissing with!
To merit bliss by making me despair:
To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid
To mine own children in good bringing up:
To mingle faith with him! Undone! undone!
To miseries enough; no hope to help you,
To mitigate the scorn he gives his uncle,
To monarchize, be fear'd and kill with looks,
To more approved service and desert.
To most ignoble stooping.
To most that teach.
To move is to stir; and to be valiant is to stand:
To move the heavens to smile upon my state,
To murder her I married.
To murder me and my good Lord of Gloucester?
To murder me?
To murder, murder our solemnity?
To my daughters; and tell them both,
To my house. Fare you well.
To my inheritance of free descent.
To my proceedings, if, with pure heart's love,
To name the bigger light, and how the less,
To no apparent likelihood of breach,
To no sight but thine and mine, invisible
To nothing but despair. A thousand knees
To nothing temporal.
To o'erthrow law and in one self-born hour
To offer service to the Duke of Hereford,
To offer war where they should kneel for peace;
To old Baptista as a schoolmaster
To old Free-town, our common judgment-place.
To one that can my part in him advertise;
To one that would do thus. I am half through;
To one whom they had punish'd.
To oppose his hatred fully. Welcome home.
To our gross selves? Good, good my lord, bethink you;
To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries!
To painful labour both by sea and land,
To paly ashes, thy eyes' windows fall,
To pardon him that hath from nature stolen
To pardon me yet for a night or two,
To part the queen's proud kindred from the king.
To pass assurance of a dower in marriage
To pay their awful duty to our presence?
To plague thee for thy foul misleading me.
To plant and o'erwhelm custom. Let me pass
To plant unrightful kings, wilt know again,
To play the broker in mine own behalf;
To please the king I did; to please myself
To plot, contrive, or complot any ill
To pluck away their power, as now at last
To pluck him headlong from the usurped throne.
To pluck on others.
To prate and talk for life and honour 'fore
To prattle for himself.
To pray for them that have done scathe to us.
To press before thy father to a grave?
To prick thy finger, though to wound his heart:
To princely Richard and to Buckingham.
To prison with her! Shall we thus permit
To prison, eyes, ne'er look on liberty!
To prove him tyrant this reason may suffice,
To prove him, in defending of myself,
To prove it on thee to the extremest point
To prove myself a loyal gentleman
To prove the Duke of Norfolk, Thomas Mowbray,
To prove, by God's grace and my body's valour,
To purge herself with words: dispatch.
To put apart these your attendants, I
To put on better ere he go to church.
To put you to't. But come; our dance, I pray:
To qualify in others: were he meal'd with that
To question of his apprehension.
To quicken your increase, I will beget
To rain a shower of commanded tears,
To raise a spirit in his mistress' circle
To raise my state to title of a queen,
To raze one title of your honour out:
To reach at victory above my head,
To read a lecture of them? If thou wouldst,
To reap the harvest of perpetual peace
To reconcile me to his friendly peace:
To rest mistrustful where a noble heart
To revel in the entrails of my lambs.
To revel it with him and his new bride.'
To revel it with him and his new bride:
To rid her from this second marriage,
To rid the realm of this pernicious blot?
To rouse his wrongs and chase them to the bay.
To rouse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:
To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.
To run upon the sharp wind of the north,
To sacred Delphos, to Apollo's temple,
To satisfy your highness and the entreaties
To save at least the heir of Edward's right:
To save her life, I'll say she is not so.
To save me from the danger that might come
To save the Romans, thereby to destroy
To save the innocent: any thing possible.
To save this bastard's life,--for 'tis a bastard,
To save this brat's life?
To save this brother's life?
To save your life in this extremity,
To say 'Beseech you, cease.' You have made fair hands,
To say 'King Richard:' alack the heavy day
To say 'not guilty:' mine integrity
To say 'she is a goodly lady,' and
To say extremity was the trier of spirits;
To say he'll turn your current in a ditch,
To say this boy were like me. Come, sir page,
To say to me that thou art out of breath?
To say you have seen a better.
To scarlet indignation and bedew
To scorn at our solemnity this night.
To search the secret treasons of the world:
To season love, that of it doth not taste!
To see a goodlier man.
To see alike mine honour as their profits,
To see fair Padua, nursery of arts,
To see her in your arms.
To see her noble lord restored to health,
To see her women? any of them? Emilia?
To see him any more,--cast your good counsels
To see his nobleness!
To see how inly sorrow gripes his soul.
To see if any mean to shrink from me.
To see inherited my very wishes
To see it tetchy and fall out with the dug!
To see my friends in Padua, but of all
To see the life as lively mock'd as ever
To see the statue of our queen: your gallery
To see these honours in possession.
To see this business. To-morrow next
To see this sight, it irks my very soul.
To see thy son and heir more early down.
To see you are become so penitent.
To see you so attired, sworn, I think,
To see your wives dishonour'd to your noses,--
To see, now, how a jest shall come about!
To seek him here that means not to be found.
To seek out sorrow that dwells every where.
To seek the empty, vast and wandering air;
To seek their fortunes farther than at home
To seek to put me down and reign thyself.
To send for Titus Lartius, it remains,
To serve me last, that I may longest keep
To serve me well, you all should do me duty,
To set him free from his captivity.
To set my brother Clarence and the king
To set the crown once more on Henry's head:
To several subjects. Heaven hath my empty words;
To shame unvulnerable, and stick i' the wars
To shape my legs of an unequal size;
To shepherds looking on their silly sheep,
To show myself a glass.
To show the world I am a gentleman.
To shrink mine arm up like a wither'd shrub;
To shun the danger that his soul divines.
To signify thou camest to bite the world:
To sin in loving virtue: never could the strumpet,
To sin's rebuke and my Creator's praise.
To sing them too: when you do dance, I wish you
To sit about the coronation.
To sit upon a hill, as I do now,
To slay the innocent? What is my offence?
To smile at scapes and perils overblown.
To smooth his fault I should have been more mild:
To soar with his light feathers, and so bound,
To soften Angelo: and that's my pith of business
To some man else, as this dead man doth me.
To some more fitter place, and that with speed.
To some remote and desert place quite out
To speak before your time. Proceed.
To speak of Perdita, now grown in grace
To speak of peace or war.
To speak so indirectly I am loath:
To speak with Coriolanus.
To speak with you; may it please you to come down.
To speak your deeds, not little of his care
To speak, as from his mouth, what he doth know
To spend the time to end it.
To stain the temper of my knightly sword.
To stale 't a little more.
To stand upon my kingdom once again.
To stay him from the fall of vanity:
To stir against the butchers of his life!
To stop all hopes whose growth may damage me.
To stop devoted charitable deeds?
To stop the inundation of her tears;
To strengthen and support King Edward's place.
To strew him o'er and o'er!
To strike him dead, I hold it not a sin.
To strive for that which resteth in my choice:
To strut before a wanton ambling nymph;
To study fashions to adorn my body:
To such a greeting: villain am I none;
To such abhorr'd pollution.
To suck the sweets of sweet philosophy.
To sue to live, I find I seek to die;
To suffer lawful censure for such faults
To sunder his that was thine enemy?
To sunder them that yoke so well together.
To supper; to our house.
To swear him in the justice of his cause.
To swim, to dive into the fire, to ride
To take advantage of the absent time
To take her in her heart's extremest hate,
To take in many towns ere almost Rome
To take is not to give.
To take off so much grief from you as he
To take on me to keep and kill thy heart.
To take our brother Clarence to your grace.
To take the one the other, by some chance,
To take the urgent hour. Come, sir, away.
To take their rooms, ere I can place myself:
To tame a shrew and charm her chattering tongue.
To taste of thy most worst? Thy tyranny
To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?
To teach you gamut in a briefer sort,
To tear with thunder the wide cheeks o' the air,
To teeming foison, even so her plenteous womb
To tell thee plain, I aim to lie with thee.
To tell thee whence thou camest, of whom derived,
To tell us whether they will come or no!
To tell you plain, I had rather lie in prison.
To tell, he longs to see his son, were strong:
To the Capitol, come:
To the contrary I have express commandment.
To the corruption of a blemished stock:
To the dead bodies of my queen and son:
To the dead bodies: I will apprehend him.
To the discontented members, the mutinous parts
To the disgrace and downfall of your house:
To the duke himself, to tax him with injustice?
To the end of reckoning.
To the ensuing age abhorr'd.' Speak to me, son:
To the fairness of my power.
To the freshest things now reigning and make stale
To the greater bench: in a rebellion,
To the ground, mistress.
To the hopeful execution do I leave you
To the house of Signior Baptista Minola?
To the lascivious pleasing of a lute.
To the most of men this is a Caliban
To the noble heart. What's gone and what's past help
To the palace, an it like your worship.
To the people! Coriolanus, patience!
To the people, beg their stinking breaths.
To the people; not by your own instruction,
To the possession of thy royal hand:
To the pot, I warrant him.
To the rock, to the rock with him!
To the shore, that o'er his wave-worn basis bow'd,
To the strict deputy; bid herself assay him:
To the syllable.
To the under generation, you shall find
To the utmost of a man, and giddy censure
To the vulgar eye, that he bears all things fairly.
To the winds whose pity, sighing back again,
To thee I do commend my watchful soul,
To thee I pray; sweet Clifford, pity me!
To thee particularly and to all the Volsces
To thee, herself, and many a Christian soul,
To thee, that hast nor honesty nor grace.
To them accordingly.
To think I can be undiscernible,
To think but nobly of my grandmother:
To think it should leave crying and say 'Ay.'
To think it was so? O, give me thy hand,
To think o' the teen that I have turn'd you to,
To think our former state a happy dream;
To think upon you.
To think your father, by some accident,
To this most patient, sweet and virtuous wife:
To this my fair beloved: therefore, I pray you,
To this pernicious caitiff deputy,--
To this same place, to this same monument.
To this submission. Yet I well remember
To this supposed, or else to let him suffer;
To this their late escape.
To those whose dealings have deserved the place,
To thread the postern of a small needle's eye.'
To threaten me with death is most unlawful.
To three thousand dolours a year.
To thrust the lie unto him.
To thy false seeming! Blood, thou art blood:
To tie thee to my strong correction.
To tire your royalty.
To torture thee the more, being what thou art.
To touch his growth nearer than he touch'd mine.
To trash for over-topping, new created
To triumph, like an Amazonian trull,
To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers
To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo
To try if thou be current gold indeed
To turn their own points on their masters' bosoms:
To turn your households' rancour to pure love.
To twinkle in their spheres till they return.
To unbuild the city and to lay all flat.
To undeck the pompous body of a king;
To undercrest your good addition
To undergo such ample grace and honour,
To undertake the death of all the world,
To unloose this tied-up justice when you pleased:
To unpath'd waters, undream'd shores, most certain
To unstable slightness: purpose so barr'd,
To upstart unthrifts? Wherefore was I born?
To us that give you truly: by your patience,
To use it for my time: I am a brother
To use it like a giant.
To use my lawful sword!
To use my wings. Impute it not a crime
To vice you to't, that you have touch'd his queen
To visit him to-morrow or next day:
To visit the next room, I'll presently
To voice him consul: lay the fault on us.
To wail the dimming of our shining star;
To wail the tide, as her mother doth.
To wake our peace, which in our country's cradle
To warn false traitors from the like attempts.
To wash this blood off from my guilty hand:
To watch the fearful bending of thy knee,
To watch the night in storms, the day in cold,
To watch the waning of mine adversaries.
To wayward sickliness and age in him:
To weed my vice and let his grow!
To weep is to make less the depth of grief:
To what tune pleased his ear; that now he was
To what we fear of death.
To what we wildly do, so we profess
To what, I pray?
To where you are bound, you must inquire your way,
To whom God will, there be the victory!
To whom I am subdued, are but light to me,
To whom I will retail my conquest won,
To whom do lions cast their gentle looks?
To whom in all this presence speaks your grace?
To whom my father is not all unknown;
To whom should I complain? Did I tell this,
To whom the heavens in thy nativity
To whom they go to. What will you read to her?
To whom we all rest generally beholding.
To whom, my lord?
To whose flint bosom my condemned lord
To whose foul mouth no healthsome air breathes in,
To whose high will we bound our calm contents.
To wield old partisans, in hands as old,
To wife for Edward: if this news be true,
To win a vulgar station: or veil'd dames
To win our daughter.
To win thy after-love I pardon thee.
To wish me wed to one half lunatic;
To wit, an indigested and deformed lump,
To women of all fashion; lastly, hurried
To worry lambs and lap their gentle blood,
To worthy danger and deserved death.
To wound thy lord, thy king, thy governor:
To wreak the love I bore my cousin
To yield the ghost: but still the envious flood
To yield what passes here.
To yield your voices?
To you a charge and trouble: to save both,
To you and toward your friend, whose love had spoke,
To you and your behests, and am enjoin'd
To you, my lord, I come, what lord you will,
To your good prayers will scarcely say amen.
To your high presence.
To your own bents dispose you: you'll be found,
To your own conscience, sir, before Polixenes
To your remembrances: but you have found,
To your worship's house, sir?
To, to, to--
To-day shalt thou behold a subject die
To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.
To-day, as I came by, I called there;
To-day, to-day, unhappy day, too late,
To-morrow I intend to hunt again.
To-morrow are let blood at Pomfret-castle;
To-morrow night look that thou lie alone;
To-morrow then belike shall be the day,
To-morrow will I send.
To-morrow will it please you to be crown'd?
To-morrow you set on.
To-morrow! O, that's sudden! Spare him, spare him!
To-morrow's vengeance on the head of Richard.
To-morrow, in mine opinion, is too sudden;
To-morrow, or next day, they will be here.
To-morrow, then, I judge a happy day.
To-morrow, then, we will attend your grace:
To-morrow; to-day; presently; you shall have the
To-night she is mew'd up to her heaviness.
Together with the seal o' the senate, what
Together with the terror of the place,--
Together working with thy jealousies,
Told me, the king, provoked by the queen,
Told the sad story of my father's death,
Told thee no lies, made thee no mistakings, served
Tongue far from heart--play with all virgins so:
Tongue-tied ambition, not replying, yielded
Tongue-tied, our queen?
Too ceremonious and traditional
Too deep and dead, poor infants, in their grave.
Too early seen unknown, and known too late!
Too familiar
Too far i' the land: 'tis like to be loud weather;
Too far in years to be a pupil now:
Too flattering-sweet to be substantial.
Too good to be so and too bad to live,
Too great for what contains it. Boy! O slave!
Too great oppression for a tender thing.
Too late he died that might have kept that title,
Too late? why, no; I, that do speak a word.
Too light for such a swain as you to catch;
Too like the lightning, which doth cease to be
Too little payment for so great a debt.
Too modest are you;
Too much hair there, but in a semicircle
Too noble for this place.
Too proud to be so valiant.
Too rude, too boisterous, and it pricks like thorn.
Too swift arrives as tardy as too slow.
Too well, too well thou tell'st a tale so ill.
Took pains to make thee speak, taught thee each hour
Torment myself to catch the English crown:
Torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
Touch'd you the bastardy of Edward's children?
Touches me deeper than you can imagine.
Touching King Henry's oath and your succession.
Touching that point.
Touching the jointure that your king must make,
Touching the weal o' the common, you shall find
Towards Chertsey, noble lord?
Towards Ludlow then, for we'll not stay behind.
Towards Phoebus' lodging: such a wagoner
Towards her deserved children is enroll'd
Towards him I made, but he was ware of me
Towards our assistance we do seize to us
Tradition, form and ceremonious duty,
Trail your steel pikes. Though in this city he
Traitor! how now!
Traitors!
Tranio is changed into Lucentio.
Tranio, I burn, I pine, I perish, Tranio,
Tranio, I saw her coral lips to move
Tranio, be so, because Lucentio loves:
Tranio, let's go: one thing more rests, that
Tranio, since for the great desire I had
Tranio, you jest: but have you both forsworn me?
Transform'd and weaken'd? hath Bolingbroke deposed
Translate his malice towards you into love,
Transparent heretics, be burnt for liars!
Travel you far on, or are you at the farthest?
Travelling some journey, to repose him here.
Tread not upon him. Masters all, be quiet;
Tread on the sand; why, there you quickly sink:
Treason! foul treason! Villain! traitor! slave!
Tremble and start at wagging of a straw,
Tremble at patience. You, my lord, best know,
Trembled and shook; for why, he stamp'd and swore,
Tressel and Berkeley, go along with me.
Tribunes, give way; he shall to the market-place.
Trimm'd like a younker prancing to his love!
Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about you;

Unless I have mista'en his colours much,

Wailing our losses, whiles the foe doth rage;

Wanting the manage of unruly jades.
Warm and new kill'd.
Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not,

Warwick is chancellor and the lord of Calais;
Warwick may lose, that now hath won the day.
Warwick, although my head still wear the crown,
Warwick, these words have turn'd my hate to love;

Warwick, what are thy news? and yours, fair queen?
Was Ajax, call'd so from his grandfather.
Was Duke of Milan; and thou his only heir
Was I then to you!
Was Tybalt's dooms-day, whose untimely death
Was aptly fitted and naturally perform'd.
Was brow-bound with the oak. His pupil age
Was crown'd in Paris but at nine months old.
Was done to death? and more than so, my father,
Was dukedom large enough: of temporal royalties
Was ever book containing such vile matter
Was ever father so bemoan'd his son?
Was ever gentleman thus grieved as I?
Was ever king so grieved for subjects' woe?
Was ever man so proud as is this Marcius?
Was ever match clapp'd up so suddenly?
Was ever son so rued a father's death?
Was ever woman in this humour won?
Was ever woman in this humour woo'd?
Was fast belock'd in thine; this is the body
Was grown into a hoop? hast thou forgot her?
Was he met there? his train? Camillo with him?
Was his great ancestor.
Was in the wreck; and, but he's something stain'd
Was innocence for innocence; we knew not
Was it more precious to me than 'tis now:
Was it not she and that good man of worship,
Was it not so?
Was it not to refresh the mind of man
Was like to be the best.
Was mutually committed?
Was my beloved in Rome: yet thou behold'st!
Was my great father-in-law, renowned Warwick;
Was ne'er distributed.
Was never mother had so dear a loss!
Was never widow had so dear a loss!
Was not Gaunt just, and is not Harry true?
Was not a man my father? Hadst thou foxship

Was not our recompense, resting well assured

Was the first man that leap'd; cried, 'Hell is empty

Was woe enough, if it had ended there:
Was wont to cheer his dad in mutinies?

We all have strongly sworn to give him aid;
We are accounted poor citizens, the patricians good.
We are advertised by our loving friends
We are all frail.
We are all undone, unless
We are amazed; and thus long have we stood

We are but plain fellows, sir.

We are fit to bid her welcome.
We are inforced to farm our royal realm;
We are less afraid to be drowned than thou art.
We are lucky, boy; and to be so still requires
We are merely cheated of our lives by drunkards:

We are not, sir, nor are we like to be;
We are the greater poll, and in true fear

We can: my royal liege,

We cannot without circumstance descry.
We cannot, sir, we are undone already.
We charge you, in God's name, and the king's,
We charge you, that you have contrived to take
We come to use our hands and not our tongues.
We could at once put us in readiness,

We do condemn thee to the very block
We do debase ourselves, cousin, do we not,

We do it not alone, sir.
We do request your kindest ears, and after,
We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.
We follow thee.
We follow'd then our lord, our lawful king:
We give thee up our guiltless blood to drink.
We had the tune on't a month ago.
We hate alike:

We have a trifling foolish banquet towards.
We have always truly served you, and beseech you
We have as many friends as enemies.
We have at disadvantage fought and did
We have been called so of many; not that our heads
We have been down together in my sleep,
We have compounded on.
We have deserved it.
We have ever your good word.

We have: whereupon the Earl of Worcester

We know thy charge, Brakenbury, and will obey.
We know your drift: speak what?
We know't, we know't.
We let the people know't.
We live to tell it you, the subtle traitor
We lop away, that bearing boughs may live:
We make woe wanton with this fond delay:
We may digest our complots in some form.
We may live, son, to shed many more.
We may surprise and take him at our pleasure?
We may, sir, if we will.
We met here both to thank and to remember
We met, we woo'd and made exchange of vow,
We might recover all our loss again;
We must be brief when traitors brave the field.
We must be neat; not neat, but cleanly, captain:
We must both give and take, my gracious lord.
We must not make a scarecrow of the law,
We must proceed as we do find the people.
We must suggest the people in what hatred
We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns,
We must talk in secret:--nurse, come back again;
We need no grave to bury honesty:
We need no more of your advice: the matter,
We need not put new matter to his charge:
We never yet made doubt but Rome was ready
We pout upon the morning, are unapt
We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.
We pray with heart and soul and all beside:
We prove this very hour.
We recommend to you, tribunes of the people,
We render you the tenth, to be ta'en forth,
We say that Shore's wife hath a pretty foot,
We see the ground whereon these woes do lie;
We see the very wreck that we must suffer;
We see the wind sit sore upon our sails,
We set the axe to thy usurping root;
We shall be blest to do, if he remember
We shall be charged again. Whiles we have struck,
We shall be joyful of thy company.
We shall be much unfurnished for this time.
We shall be short in our provision:
We shall be shorten'd in our aim, which was
We shall entreat you to abide here till he come and
We shall not marry till thou bid'st us.
We shall proceed with Angelo.
We shill employ thee in a worthier place.
We should by this, to all our lamentation,

We stay here for the people.
We still have known thee for a holy man.
We stood to't in good time.
We sucking on her natural bosom find,

We thank thee, gentle Percy, for thy pains;
We thank you both: yet one but flatters us,
We thank your honour.
We three are but thyself; and, speaking so,
We three are married, but you two are sped.
We three here art that ne'er shall meet again.
We took this mattock and this spade from him,
We tread upon, and never think of it.
We two have sworn shall come.
We two, my lord,
We wait upon your grace.
We waste our lights in vain, like lamps by day.
We were as twinn'd lambs that did frisk i' the sun,

We were, fair queen,

We will descend and fold him in our arms.
We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow:
We will go walk a little in the orchard,
We will have rings and things and fine array;
We will have vengeance for it, fear thou not:
We will meet them,
We will not from the helm to sit and weep,
We will ourself in person to this war:
We will persuade him, be it possible,
We will so: almost all

We will, my noble lord.
We would as willingly give cure as know.
We would so, and then go a bat-fowling.

We'll part the time between's then; and in that
We'll pass the business privately and well.
We'll quickly rouse the traitors in the same.

Went all afoot in summer's scalding heat,
Went they not quickly, I should die with laughing.
Went through the army, cheering up the soldiers.

Whate'er I read to her, I'll plead for you
Whate'er it be, be thou still like thyself,
Whate'er it bodes, henceforward will I bear
Whate'er thou hear'st or seest, stand all aloof,
Whatever I shall happen to devise.
Whatever fortune stays him from his word:
When Biondello comes, he waits on thee;
When Bolingbroke rode on roan Barbary,
When Clifford cannot spare his friends an oath.
When I am alone, why, then I am Tranio;
When I am cold in zeal to yours.
When I arrived and heard thee, that made gape
When I do see the very book indeed
When I have deck'd the sea with drops full salt,
When I have fought with Pembroke and his fellows,
When I have heard your king's desert recounted,
When I have most need to employ a friend,
When I have said, cry 'woe!' the queen, the queen,
When I perceive your grace, like power divine,
When I return with victory from the field
When I said, banish him, I said 'twas pity.
When I shall ask the banns and when be married.
When I shall gust it last. How came't, Camillo,
When I shall see this gentleman, thy speeches
When I should bid good morrow to my bride,
When I should mount with wings of victory:
When I was crown'd I was but nine months old.
When I was last in Holborn,
When I wore it at your daughter's marriage?
When I would pray and think, I think and pray
When I'll depose I had him in mine arms
When I, that censure him, do so offend,
When I, thy three-hours wife, have mangled it?
When King Cophetua loved the beggar-maid!
When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,
When Richmond was a little peevish boy.
When Tarquin made a head for Rome, he fought
When as the enemy hath been ten to one:
When as the noble Duke of York was slain,
When black-faced Clifford shook his sword at him;
When blows have made me stay, I fled from words.
When but love's shadows are so rich in joy!
When care, mistrust, and treason waits on him.
When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks;
When corn was given them gratis, you repined;
When daffodils begin to peer,
When did she cross thee with a bitter word?
When didst thou sleep when such a deed was done?
When dying clouds contend with growing light,
When every grief is entertain'd that's offer'd,
When evil deeds have their permissive pass
When first I did embrace him: yet his nature
When gallant-springing brave Plantagenet,
When good manners shall lie all in one or two men's
When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand;
When have I injured thee? when done thee wrong?
When he bestrides the lazy-pacing clouds
When he did need your loves, and do you think
When he did stand for consul, which he lost
When he doth bid good morrow with such a spirit.
When he had carried Rome and that we look'd
When he had done, some followers of mine own,
When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies
When he might act the woman in the scene,
When he might spurn him with his foot away?
When he perceives the envious clouds are bent
When he shall miss me,--as, in faith, I mean not
When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,
When he stands where I am and sees you there.
When he wakes! why, fool, he shall never wake till
When he would force it? Sure, it is no sin,
When holy Harry died, and my sweet son.
When holy and devout religious men
When it deserves, with characters of brass,
When it did taste the wormwood on the nipple
When it doth tax itself; as these black masks
When it hoars ere it be spent.
When it is baked with frost.
When it is least expected.
When it lies starkly in the traveller's bones:
When it was less expected: he replied,
When judges steal themselves. What, do I love her,
When men are unprepared and look not for it.
When men were fond, I smiled and wonder'd how.
When most struck home, being gentle wounded, craves
When most the truth; which I receive much better
When must he die?
When my good falcon made her flight across
When my poor heart no measure keeps in grief:
When nature brought him to the door of death?
When nights are longest there: I'll take my leave.
When once she is my wife.
When one but of my ordinance stood up
When our sea-walled garden, the whole land,
When presently through all thy veins shall run
When scarce the blood was well wash'd from his hands
When she did suckle Hector, look'd not lovelier
When she does praise me grieves me. I have done
When she was young you woo'd her; now in age
When she will play with reason and discourse,
When she will take the rein I let her run;
When she, poor hen, fond of no second brood,
When steel grows soft as the parasite's silk,
When such a sacred king should hide his head.
When such bad dealings must be seen in thought.
When the alarum were struck than idly sit
When the devout religion of mine eye
When the sea is. Hence! What cares these roarers
When the sun sets, the air doth drizzle dew;
When the sun sets, who doth not look for night?
When the tongue's office should be prodigal
When theirs are dry, for Romeo's banishment.
When they are bound to serve, love and obey.
When they are gone, then must I count my gains.
When they do homage to this simple peasant.
When they should serve their sovereign in the west?
When this is known, then to divide the times:
When thou comest thither--
When thou didst bower the spirit of a fiend
When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper
When thou hast broke it in so dear degree?
When thou mayst tell thy tale a nearer way?
When thou wert king; who, travelling towards York,
When time is broke and no proportion kept!
When time shall call him home from banishment,
When triumph is become an alehouse guest?
When we grow stronger, then we'll make our claim:
When we shall hap to give 't them.
When we were chosen tribunes for the people,--
When weeping made you break the story off,
When well-apparell'd April on the heel
When what's not meet, but what must be, was law,
When will he be here?
When with his Amazonian chin he drove
When with his knees he kiss'd the Cretan strand.
When you and I met at Saint Alban's last,
When you are cloudy.
When you are gentle, you shall have one too,
When you cast out, it still came home.
When you curse them as enemies.
When you depart from him, but, soft and low,
When you depart, and save your thanks. How say you?
When you disgraced me in my embassade,
When you have done, repair to Crosby Place.
When you have said 'she's goodly,' come between
When you have vow'd, you must not speak with men
When you shall come to clearer knowledge, that
When you should bring the plaster.

Where 'tis predominant; and 'tis powerful, think it,
Where Claudio stoop'd to death, and with like haste.
Where I arrive, and my approach be shunn'd,
Where I have learn'd me to repent the sin
Where I have seen corruption boil and bubble
Where I may read who pass'd that passing fair?
Where I must take like seat unto my fortune,
Where I shall kneel to him that slew my father!

Where all my sins are writ, and that's myself.

Where lies he?
Where my poor young was limed, was caught and kill'd.
Where no man never comes but that sad dog
Where no priest shovels in dust. O cursed wretch,
Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us
Where nothing lives but crosses, cares and grief.
Where of the execution did cry out
Where on a sudden one hath wounded me,
Where one on his side fights, thousands will fly.
Where one part does disdain with cause, the other
Where our right valiant father is become.
Where peremptory Warwick now remains:
Where rude misgovern'd hands from windows' tops
Where senators shall mingle tears with smiles,
Where serpents are; chain me with roaring bears;
Where shall we dine? O me! What fray was here?
Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?
Where shame doth harbour, even in Mowbray's face.
Where she at least is banish'd from your eye,
Where shivering cold and sickness pines the clime;
Where should be graven, if that right were right,
Where should she be? How oddly thou repliest!
Where should this music be? i' the air or the earth?
Where sits deformity to mock my body;
Where slept our scouts, or how are they seduced,
Where small experience grows. But in a few,
Where that same banish'd runagate doth live,
Where the devil should this Romeo be?
Where the disease is violent. Lay hands upon him,
Where the infectious pestilence did reign,
Where the warlike Smalus,
Where then, alas, may I complain myself?
Where they shall know our mind: away!
Where thou shalt live, till we can find a time
Where thou shalt rest, that thou mayst hear of us
Where we were lodgers at the Pegasus.
Where we're offenders now, appear soul-vex'd,
Where were her life? she durst not call me so,
Where were you born, friend?
Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard.
Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain,
Where you may have such vantage on the duke,
Where you shall be an everlasting leiger:
Where you shall find me well accompanied
Where you were tied in duty, and as sorry
Where you'll be loath to be: besides you know
Where your brave father breathed his latest gasp,
Where youth, and cost, and witless bravery keeps.
Where'er I wander, boast of this I can,
Where'er it be, in heaven or in earth.

Wherein I seem unnatural: desire not

Wherein the acorn cradled. Follow.
Wherein the king stands generally condemn'd.

Wherein thy counsel and consent is wanting.
Wherein thyself shalt highly be employ'd.
Wherein you see me smear'd; if any fear
Wherein your cunning can assist me much.
